HelpFactor:
Support Services and programs on campus like the Transfer Center, AAP, Financial Wellness Program, CPO, Peer mentors, and Counseling departments have helped me tremendously. 
Building supportive friend groups and networks allowed me to overcome several obstacles through solidarity. 
Having emotionally-supportive loved ones helped me to combat my anxiety.
InhibitFactor:
The transfer process was very difficult for the first year-having to adjust and adapt in a new environment and community. The process did not end in the first year as I immediately had to go through moving and re-settling in the city of Los Angeles for the second year at UCLA. It feels like there was very little time for transfers to get accustomed and fit in. For this reason I find a sense of belonging at a smaller scale with my small groups of friends and loved ones versus feeling like a belong in UCLA in the larger university community or in the surrounding city.
Throughout my entire time in UCLA, I have felt my anxiety heighten; however, it is through solidarity with others in similar situations that I have built resiliency.

HelpFactor: The faultiest are nice and wish to help, my friends help me a lot and most of the professors are willing to help us success.
InhibitFactor: I guess myself inhibited my success at UCLA, since I am not confident to join a club that I interested, and I need my friends accompanying, otherwise, I would feel lonely. Most of time, I am easy to be distracted by other things and hard to focus on my assignments.

HelpFactor: The main factor that helped me was through building community, meaning finding my friend group. Having a strong friend group allows me to feel safe, supported, acknowledged, and most importantly happy at UCLA.
InhibitFactor: Myself. I am my biggest enemy, weather it is being too scared to make friends during freshman year or afraid to speak up during class. I believe you are your own worst enemy so it is important to always push yourself and change your mindset for the better.

HelpFactor: I have to say that my pre-college education prepared me a lot to succeed academically in UCLA. Because I received relatively intense math training back in China, I can handle/manage to handle most of the STEM materials in college. Many people think that STEM students are smart, but from my own experience I would say that all my success, if any, are own to practice or training that cumulated since I was very young.
InhibitFactor: The most significant difficulty that comes to me is to figure out what I want to do after college. UCLA is such a huge school and it can be hard for freshmen to connect with seniors or others to seek help about future plans. For my first two years at UCLA, I was very lost and felt like there were only things that I didn't want to do. It is very hard to achieve anything when you don't even know what you want to achieve. Although through later exploration and by luck I was able to figure out my goal, it could have been so much easier if I was able to do so at an earlier time.

HelpFactor: Definitely parental support. Without them it'd be possible.
InhibitFactor: Definitely parental support. Without them it'd be possible.

HelpFactor: Having a support group in my friends has helped me immensely.
InhibitFactor: Sometimes when I go to office hours, I'm scared to explain what I don't know to my professor in fear of being mocked or shamed for being behind. Thus, when I feel I am starting to get behind, it's just exponential because I'm too afraid to ask. Some professors I have had are impossible to keep up with and if you can't, they make you feel like you're too dumb to be in the major. I got a C in a lower division math pre-req for the Stats major(I had already taken a few upper division Stat classes averaging B grades) and I sought the Stats Academic counselor Lori. She told me that Statistics might not be the best major for me and told me to "consider" and easier major that had less math. I didn't-I'm graduating in Spring with at Stats degree.

HelpFactor: I think my primary education played a huge role in my success academically at UCLA. I come from a very wealthy, predominantly white school in Michigan, and it was one of the best public schools in the state. Thus, the teachers were really great due to how much money our school district had. My school offered many AP courses, so I was able to take many difficult and challenging classes that pushed me to improve my critical thinking skills, studying habits, and more. I honestly feel as though my high school was much harder than college, as I had hours and hours of homework every night, and I studied way more in high school.
InhibitFactor: Although transitioning from high school to college was a breeze in terms of academics, I had a much harder time developing a social life at UCLA. My entire first quarter my freshman year, I had no friends and was very homesick and depressed. I actually wanted to drop out of UCLA and move back home, and I felt like I made a horrible decision in going to what I thought was my "dream school." I feel as though it was because the town I was from in Michigan was very small, and everyone from my high school had their own small "bubble" that we stayed in for all K-12 years of schooling. I went to school with the same exact people for 13 years, so it was really hard for me to move away from this tight-knit community to an institution that is 10x the size. Eventually, though, I made more friends in one of the clubs I had been in since my first month of college, and from that, I was able to develop more social skills and pushed myself to make more friends in classes and other clubs.

HelpFactor: To be not procrastinate is really important in finishing tasks no matter academically or socially.
InhibitFactor: procrastination sometimes inhibits my success and ruins my emotions

HelpFactor: Supportive family and friends are the biggest factor. Switching out of a STEM major also significantly improved my quality of life. These majors, especially at UCLA, prevent students from having any sort of life outside of university.
InhibitFactor: As a student who initially entered the university system expecting to graduate in a STEM field, I found many of the ‘introductory courses’ (such as biology & chemistry) to be especially difficult. These “weeder” classes are usually a student’s first impression of their major and often lead to many freshman switching majors. I experienced, first hand, that these classes are not only difficult but they actually discourage students from continuing in the STEM field. It is completely standardized and curved against the average student and for that reason many people are unable to succeed. Even though I passed my science classes at UCLA with an A, it came at a cost.

HelpFactor: Growing up in a family that emphasized education and academic success instilled in me a drive to achieve. In addition, I was frequently surrounded my friends who shared the same mindset, which allowed us to mutually support and relate to each other's experiences. I was able to carry this with me to UCLA, which allowed me to succeed at the university.
InhibitFactor: While I have always had a strong desire to achieve, the immense amount of pressure I put on myself has made it more difficult to see my experience as "successful." Since my family and I place such high expectations on my performance, I struggle to balance my various obligations, consequently affected my social and emotional success.

1. Advisors(stats dept) are not familiar with staff that they should have been familiar with. 

2. They(stats dept) do not care about students enough, especially for those who are not stats major students. 

I had a horrible experience with stats advisors and they delayed my academic progress on stats minor for 2 quarters with both advisors' discrepancy and non-consistency with stats prerequisites classes. I heard many students had same experience of mine in terms of dealing their issues and questions in double or minor major with stats with advisors in stats dept. I even heard the manager of classes(I am not quite sure his title) said " You'd better declare stats major ASAP, I don't want to see you again" to a student which I think was pretty rude and discouraging. These words should not come from an educator or even a staff from a university. 

3. Maybe because UCLA has too many students that the class schedule is hard to accommodate all students. 

My sister is also a math and stats student graduating from UC Berkeley. Compared to her experience in UCB, I feel like UCB's registration system is more advanced than ours and UCB provides more flexibility to students to choose classes with their flexible prerequisite class requirement and cross-department classes enrollment. As long as you think you could handle it and the professor is willing to add you into the class, it's no problem to attend higher sequence classes regardless the prerequisite requirement or if it is cross-department/cross-major class which makes students have as many as possibilities to explore and succeed in their college life. 
I don't think UCLA cares about this, the staff just cares about killing the line outside their office and wants you to leave the office with no concern of whether your problem has been solved. 
To further illustrate, I would like to put my case as an example here, I took a stats10 in my community college which UCLA stats dept did not recognize it as equivalent to stats10 here and advisor A here insisted that I have to retake stat10 before taking stat20(where advisor B just manually enrolled my friend who had same situation as mine to a stat20 class, I knew this after the enrolling deadline, if not, I could have just gone to advisor B to have me added to stat20), but when I retook a stat10 here in UCLA, the registrar counted as a repetitive class so gave me zero credits of it. 
The problem exists for years without fixing and the consequence falls on students themselves including me. Because of this, I could not enroll into stat20 in 2018 fall which I should have been able to. In the later winter quarter I found out my stat10 enrollment had no credits so I dropped it with no stat20 provided in that quarter. Even then I went to stats dept, the advisor still did not care and asked me to come back next quarter when stat20 is available. In spring, I went back and the manager of classes did not solve the problem and asked me to consult with registrar why the registrar did not give credits for my stat10 here.  The staff in registrar thought it was wired that they could not do anything to a junior(at that time I was a junior) a repetitive class credits and for stats dept it was an small issue that they could just manually got around this issue and add me to stat20.  
Rather than a call to figure out this problem or even have a meeting to seriously discuss about this issue that many transfer students might have, they just let me went back and forth from the stats dept and Murphy Hall with both parties throwing their ball to the other. This was a very long story and here is just a small piece of it. After this, I felt exhausted and frustrated and do not want to make any contact with any admin staff here in UCLA. 
I have told this story to my sister who had same situation as mine that in her junior year she also needed to work with their stats dept on classes enrollment and double major declaration stuff, she never encountered any unhappiness with their dept over there in UCB and she thought it was unbelievable that our system was so rigid and inflexible because the only way for me to enroll stat20 is to 'beg' the stats dept staff to add me in as our system prevented me from enrolling higher sequence of classes which in UCB system, they won't prevent you from enrolling classes unless you acknowledge that you have full responsibility for your own academic progress and path. At that point, I was so regretful not choosing UCB over UCLA in 2018 as I got both admissions.

HelpFactor: As an international student away from home, I call my parents every week and we update new happenings to each other, including daily stories, my academic difficulties, and other social life, etc. Dosing so shortens our distance and makes me feel loving and loved.
InhibitFactor: The high tuition fee sometimes gives me pressure and always let me question myself that whether I am doing enough.

GPA: NA
HelpFactor: At UCLA, I believe that a cornucopia of factors have enabled me to find success. Academically, my professors have been very approachable during office hours--especially Professor Tsiang, who will discuss anything, even if not related to the class--allowing me to feel comfortable in asking for help when I am not certain about a certain question or material in the class. Socially and emotionally, orientation established a few close friends with whom I can spend time and in whom I can confide if I have to talk to someone. These people have been the foundation for establishing a social group here at UCLA, which has allowed me to find success and feel at home. Furthermore, because of the diverse array of organizations on campus, I have been able to find my niche--through Bruin Sports Analytics, a club which combines my love for sports with my field of interest of statistics--and meet people with similar interests, expanding my community. Also, having a gym so close to the on-campus housing allows me to remain physically fit, which in turn boosts my energy and emotional state. Overall, I believe that the resources offered by UCLA--through the campus, faculty, students, and physical resources--have enabled me to find some success as I begin my college experience as a first-year.
InhibitFactor: Because I am so new to college (I have only been in school for approximately one month), I have not encountered any factors which have inhibited my success at UCLA in any aspect of "success." Obviously, the workload here at UCLA differs from that in high school, but that change was expected and I believe I am adapting to the academic rigor of UCLA according. Ultimately, I have not experienced any inhibitions; the people whom I have met have supported my endeavors and aided me if I was confused about some event or some problem.

HelpFactor: Self-motivation; nice facility at school; friends that I can relate with.

HelpFactor: UCLA provides excellent academic resource, especially, the research opportunities are pretty helpful for stem major students.

HelpFactor: I wouldn't consider myself successful at UCLA. However, I do think I have been doing some things right that set me up for success. Having a small, close group of friends has helped me lead a balanced social life (even if the people I mostly talk to don't go here). Making clear what I know I want, and not caring about what other people thing (as best as I can) has helped reduce stress.
InhibitFactor: I think the greatest inhibitor of my success is my sheer lack of self-discipline. I would consider myself a very ambitious person with lofty goals. However, when push comes to shove I always falter and am never able to do my work diligently-- I put off assignments, studying, and exercising to guiltily indulge in escapism. This is really the main problem I have, and I understand it is a major one. If I can get myself to put in consistent effort, however little, I think I can make substantial progress as a person.

HelpFactor: In all aspects, having older friends that looked out for me my freshman year was really impactful. I had a friend that would cook for me at her apartment, help me out with figuring out how to navigates classes and such, and even let me stay over when I was feeling anxiety about my roommates. It's also because of her that I try to pass this forward!
InhibitFactor: It's really easy to get lost in the crowd at UCLA, and especially early on in my college career I was scared to go to events/things I wanted to join by myself out of fear of seeming like a loner. But it's those same things I was scared to go to that had the best results. Academically, it's hard to stay on track and study because of how much social stuff there is to do.

HelpFactor: Being a part of multiple groups on campus helps me socially on campus. This way, I interact with different groups of people which I can learn different things from. For example, I play on the club soccer team but I also participate in cultural clubs. The experience I get from both are different but both extremely rewarding. Having very supportive roommates is how I have remained mentally healthy. Going to office hours for TAs that were actually eager to help was extremely helpful.
InhibitFactor: TAs who are unapproachable and condescending when you ask questions is very discouraging and has definitely inhibited my success at UCLA. In Math 32A, my TA was not helpful at all and I struggled with the curriculum and quickly fell behind.

HelpFactor: I really like when professors upload their notes and practice problems on CCLE, because I will have sufficient resources to prepare me for exams. Also, I hope more professors can use BruinCast, where they can upload recordings of their lectures online.
InhibitFactor:
Sometimes, a course's professor is excellent, but the TAs are not really helpful. I hope we can create a website where we can not only rate professors, but also TAs. There are some TAs that have been criticized on BruinWalk, but no professors decided to change their TAs.

Also, please DON'T change the professors on the course schedule during course choosing time. Sometimes many students spent a lot of efforts in choosing a class with a fine professor. But in the end, the professor changed, leaving everyone unhappy and anxious.

HelpFactor: My roommates were great and they're my best friends now and they've kept me on track to work hard and be successful at UCLA.
InhibitFactor: The size of classes and the level of seriousness and rigor at UCLA make it intimidating to talk to other students and so I haven't met as many people as I'd like from my classes.

HelpFactor: Joining a fraternity greatly helped me succeed socially at UCLA. Emotionally, having a close friend from high school here helped a lot, especially as an incoming freshman.
InhibitFactor: Lack of focus has inhibited my academic success, both in terms of not focusing in class and not focusing on a general goal that motivates being academically successful.

InhibitFactor: Racism/insensitivity (I've become hostile to some people who made racist comments on Asians), interpersonal rifts (wasn't directly involved but it split up what was formerly a nice friend group), fire alarms, invisibility/elitism (definitely have felt overlooked in classes by my peers and professors), "subtle asian traits culture" if you know what I mean-- how a lot of people here treat Asian culture in a very superficial and homogeneous way out of a deep-rooted self-hate for their own background. That's pretty discouraging to see on a campus with so many of us, you'd think we'd have more of a genuine connection to our home countries.

HelpFactor: One part of my UCLA experience that's helped me succeed is finding a "home" through one of my student organizations, the Student Alumni Association (SAA). SAA helped create a structure I could lean on for support; weekly all-SAA meetings and committee meetings, supportive advisors, enthusiastic and welcoming members, and so on. It feels incredible to be part of an organization where I know people are cheering for me. When I'm down on myself about academics or mental health, I know there are people I can turn to to ask for help. That's definitely been a huge help for succeeding at UCLA.
InhibitFactor: I switched my major from Pre-Business Economics to Pre-Communications to now Pre-Statistics, and learning to work with students of these different majors has definitely been challenging. For example, in my Communications classes, students in my discussion sections were much more willing to discuss the course material than in my Statistics classes, where students are often much more focused on the homework and the grades. It's been difficult learning to work with students whose minds work differently and are focused on different things. This amplifies the differences in work loads as well between STEM and non-STEM classes.

HelpFactor: Student Organization Support, Advisor Support

HelpFactor: i think that being organized really helps in succeeding in many aspects at ucla. i personally really enjoy journaling and planning, so i try to do that to help me cope emotionally and academically. because it's easier to get things done when you know exactly what you need to do and by when.
InhibitFactor: i think the mindset of wanting to achieve a lot of things at ucla has really inhibited my ability to succeed because it makes me spread myself too thin and end up being a jack of all trades and king of none. one example would be how there's an enormous activities fair at the start of every school year and we always go in with renewed ambitions to do a lot of clubs and activities. but as the quarter progresses and schoolwork picks up, it. becomes harder to juggle everything and i just end up being stressed and not coping well in any aspect.

HelpFactor: I was able to find an amazing club in KCM (Korean-American Campus Missions) through which I were able to find close friends and get plugged into a local church. Through this, I was able to create a support system around me that has helped me through my struggles in college.

HelpFactor: I feel like being from a low income family of immigrants and coming from a neighborhood that was fairly diverse, I was able to come with enough stories and experiences that made me stand out to UCLA. I for one am also very good at balancing and making up for any work that I might be struggling with. Just like from this week I was able to balance finishing my homework and study for my midterms without having to pull all-nighters, though the results are still TBD. My determination to do well academically stems from my appreciation and burden to my parents. I feel like doing well in life is how I pay them back for all they've done for me, even if we disagree on the approach. Socially I have a very close nit group of friends, and while I can always depend on them, I do struggle it make many beyond them. As for my emotions, I tend to be on the more stoic side of things and try my best to stay whelmed even when under emotion stress.
InhibitFactor: The quarter system is an adjustment for sure, same with having professors. Not to say they're necessarily bad, but it's just an adjustment in pace. Socially as mentioned above I have really found a new group of friends here, just a few individuals I take to on occasion, a result of my social incompetence and shyness. Emotionally, I've been feeling very homesick, as this is the longest I've been away from home and I do miss a lot of aspects about it.

HelpFactor: My significant other is really the main cause for helping me succeed academically, socially and emotionally at UCLA. My partner understands my workload and is always there emotionally when I feel overwhelmed or when I feel like I am not good enough to be at UCLA. Everyday he gives me words or encouragement just in case there comes a day I actually need it. We use our spare time to weightlift together which really relives some tension. We also take plenty of mental breaks during studying to recuperate and calm down by cuddling to release oxytocin and dopamine along with doing breathing techniques.
InhibitFactor: There are a lot of things in my life that inhibit my success at UCLA. Every weekday, I spend at least 2.7hours driving to and from UCLA in order to make it to my classes. I also work fulltime as a caregiver for developmentally disabled adults so my daily schedule is always full. The time that I have left is spent eating, sleeping, doing class assignments and studying. This leaves me with very little time to spend with my family, partner or myself. Due to the fast pace schedule at UCLA, I find myself using all of my spare time continuously studying because I encountered my first midterms here and they are long and complex.

HelpFactor: I feel like the bruincast system literally saves my life at UCLA. I have a lot of pains and problems with my body that often prevent/ dissuade me from going to class. Bruincasted lectures allow me to not have to go to class when I am in pain. So helpful cannot be understated!
InhibitFactor: I feel like a lot of teachers don't explain things at a low enough level. I understand that I may not be the smartest student here (or anywhere near it) but I don't think that I am a complete idiot. However, some classes (especially math, computer science, etc.) expect you to have background knowledge and sometimes I am feel clueless / helpless / left behind.

HelpFactor: Figuring out the right major by taking many GE classes early on. I entered as biochem, hated Chem 20a and took stats 10 as GE winter quarter because I heard it was easy. Liked it and am now taking stats 20 thinking about a stats major.
InhibitFactor: I took a cluster in the fall of my freshman year simply because it cleared GEs faster. I hated the amount of work it took for the grades I was getting. I wanted more time to do things I was passionate about. I dropped the cluster and now only take GEs that I think I can reasonably enjoy. As a result, I've been much happier because I'm not slogging through a class I hate that doesn't even relate to my major.

HelpFactor: Joining my sorority has been hands down the biggest help in my life at UCLA. I am a very shy person, so without the social aspect of it, I would not have nearly as many friends or close connections with people as I do now. It also provides a great place to develop leadership skills and there are always girls passing down job and internship offers. I feel safe with the girls in my sorority and trust that if I ever have a problem, I can bring it to them.
InhibitFactor: My proximity to home and other friends from home has slightly inhibited my success socially at UCLA. HelpFactor:
I was in an honors program at my community college that allowed me to take less classes at UCLA to graduate. I also 
Learning about student organizations in the first week of school helped widen my social circle and meet new people with vastly different experiences.
The inclusiveness of the environment at UCLA helped me to quickly feel like I belong.
InhibitFactor:
I was in a different STEM major, Physics, when I transferred to UCLA and I felt insecure about my academic ability while I was in that major because it seemed like everyone else understood the course material and was passionate about the subject while I was struggling in class and did not have any specific career or research goals. Switching majors at the cost of needing two additional quarters to graduate was a difficult decision because I had been trying to major in Physics at UCLA since I was in high school.
I am a transfer student and only knew a couple people from my community college in Physics. The workload in the Physics major was so overwhelming I had no time to make new friends. Even after switching majors, I have yet to make a single friend at UCLA. I do no live on campus so it feels more difficult to make friends.
I was diagnosed with Major Depression and Panic Disorder in my first term at UCLA. I tried multiple medications and doses to treat them over my first year at UCLA; if they were not a good fit, it would impact my mental capacity.

HelpFactor: The most important factor for me has definitely been my roommates. They are people who I feel comfortable around almost all the time, and they are very supportive of my choices. I've tried to join many of these but was denied from all of them. I understand that being a large school, these clubs can't really take everyone or they would have literally too many people to fit in a room, but there has to be something UCLA can do. That's pretty much my biggest complaint about the school: it has too many people, meaning sometimes resources to each individual can seem limited and one can be overwhelmed in this sea of people.

HelpFactor: Friends, CAPS, external UCLA hispanic networks (HSF - Hispanic Scholarship fund held conferences of latinos across the country who also go through being minorities in their STEM class), my Bill Gates Millennium Scholarship (full ride scholarship relieved financial stress), MLT (management leadership tomorrow - a minority network like HSF)

HelpFactor: Friends' support is really important. They give me advice on academic and social life and help me get through a hard time that I feel stressed out.
InhibitFactor: A lot of advice on seeking jobs from the professors.

HelpFactor: One of the factors that has helped me is talking to others I trust. I would have changed my major if it weren't for people listening to me and telling me it'll get better, offering the help they can give help me academically and emotionally. For instance, I once went to the Director of The Curtis Center, Heather Dallas, and told her about my situation and not meeting the requirements for my major. She listened to me and told me about her struggles, then contacted one of her students to help me in my last pre-requisite course so that I can get the necessary grade to get into my major. Moreover, I had a co-worker that I told my situation to and how I felt like I was depressed, so she accompanied me to CAPS so I can talk to someone. I had other friends that just listened when I was having a breakdown, and even just having someone listen to me was helpful.
InhibitFactor: One of the factors is the environment in my classes, where I feel alone because most of the students are white or asian, and appear to understand lectures way more than me. This would make me doubt myself and block my motivation. I always compared myself to others, so when I would get a low score on an exam, I felt like I didn't belong. Moreover, I also have to commute from home, and I felt that this would take away time and affect my social life and studying.

HelpFactor:
Having a strong network of supportive friends and mentors has played a large role in my ability to succeed at UCLA. For example, I had some health issues last year and one of my friends approached me and said she'd been dealing with similar issues. The issues were affecting me both academically and emotionally, and her support really helped me get through it. 

I've also become very involved with UCLA Hillel and Jewish life on campus. Through this community, I've made so many friendships and connections that I know I will have for the rest of my life. I've grown as a student, a friend and a leader, and I can say with confidence that I wouldn't be doing as well as I am here if it weren't for this incredible community.
InhibitFactor:
As a STEM major, I sometimes feel that I'm not getting as much support from my professors and TA's as I deserve.  For example, I had a math professor for Linear Algebra who, in many ways, discouraged us from asking questions. When we did ask questions, he often provided a quick one word answer and didn't fully explain his thoughts. This experience made it harder for me to succeed in this class both because it decreased my confidence and because it made it harder for me to receive guidance and feedback. 

Though I've had several STEM professors who are very good, I am aware that STEM professors tend to exhibit this type of behavior more than non-STEM professors. I'm not exactly sure how UCLA could address this issue, but I think it is important for students of all majors to receive the support they deserve.

HelpFactor: It's all about the support groups you have, and if you don't find a smaller group that makes UCLA feel a little less big and strange, then it's inevitable—that feeling of being completely alone. Also, it's always great to have a mentor/faculty member/friend around to give perspective around an academic failure or even a success, and remind you that life is bigger than your time here. You're worth more than your performance. You're assessment in class is not an assessment of your personhood.
InhibitFactor: I'm lost in my STEM classes. I'm a north campus statistics minor, and I feel overwhelmed in my classes, which are filled with CS, math, and engineering majors who have dealt with similar problems and are taking relevant concurrent classes. I think wanting an extensive STEM background through this program is somewhat inaccessible for someone like me, and I feel really alone. For example, even in this introductory R class, people talk about this as they've also taken the PIC 10 series, or relating it to Python or C++, and I've never coded and am finding the syntax/grammar/way of thinking quite challenging.

GPA: NA
HelpFactor:
My high school was rigorous, college-path focused, and encouraged students to take many AP classes and participate in extracurricular activities. I took 11 AP classes, which I found to be more than the average number my friends took in high school. I strongly developed my planning skills and study methods, both of which I believe led to my academic success in high school and have quickly translated to my studies at UCLA. 

Coming into college, I feel that my confidence and positivity have been enhanced so that I can more easily make friends. While I love the life I have here, I still make time to call my parents and come home every two weekends to regain a sense of home where I can fully express myself after the rare emotionally frustrating times. 

Taking all of this together, I know that I have the potential to make the upcoming years in my undergraduate studies successful.
InhibitFactor: While I have already established a caring and comforting community on my residential floor, I often find myself missing out on activities that my friends do together as a result of my heavier workload (in comparison to theirs). However, I feel good staying on track with my work and ensure that I reserve time to socialize at the end of a productive day.

HelpFactor: The things that have helped me succeed are resources for both psychological and academic hardships. Having a community of people that don't foster competition and rather hope to see you succeed in your own right gives me motivation and confidence in myself despite the academic rigor of UCLA.
InhibitFactor: Having clinical anxiety and depression has been a major barrier to doing well at UCLA. I'm also a firm believer that intelligence is fixed, not in the sense that people cannot learn new or challenging things, but the ease of which someone learns something new and can apply it to real-life circumstances is a static thing. For example, challenges in STEM classes can be persistent no matter how hard you may study, it is still common not to do well. In this sense, if one doesn't have the cognitive ability to understand a subject, the amount of work they put in is irrelevant.

HelpFactor: Undergraduate Writing Center, Career Center. All those faculty centers help me a lot in my academic study.
InhibitFactor: Competitive atmosphere (but I understand somehow)

HelpFactor: I have developed a close friend group that I live with in an apartment of 6 people. Have this loving supportive environment has largely helped my mental health. InhibitFactor: My intelligence and perhaps my education. I believe the courses in college to be far more rigorous than what I experienced in high school.

This does give me a lot of stress and sometimes i feel overwhelmed and lack belief in my own abilities. I study on my own, do my work on my own, and I kind of bear all my problems on my own.

HelpFactor: It has been helpful for me not to take on too much at once. I try to balance my course load with two easy classes if I know I will be taking a challenging course that quarter. I also try to take only three classes per quarter so I can focus on those three classes while also having time for extra curriculars and spending time with friends, relaxing and working out. Also, when I came to UCLA I didn't try to join everything at once, I joined a new activity each year to ease myself into a busier schedule.
InhibitFactor: The biggest thing that has inhibited my success at UCLA has been my own anxiety especially when I let my anxiety about social situations like getting along with my roommates affect the way that I go about the rest of my life.

HelpFactor:
1. Having a strong diverse community of ambitious and empathetic people in my network has probably been the strongest guiding force in helping me grow as an individual, team member and a leader in college. I am grateful for student organisations (I am involved with an entrepreneurship fraternity Sigma Eta Pi, a VC focused club in BV) for giving me a structured curriculum and social systems to help me develop diverse set of skills. I also lucked with amazing random roommates and floormates my freshman year, and have been lucky to be around people who genuinely care about communal good. 
2. Loving parents - I have changed my major three times now and my parents have been incredibly generous and supportive through all my indepentdent decision making. They have also given me free reign in picking out a somewhat novel career path (no one in my extended family has done investment banking) and given me the freedom to pursue internship opportunities that some parents might 
3. Abundance of resources and opportunities : being in a city like LA and a campus like UCLA has blessed with an abundance of resources (academically, socially and extracurricularly) to make myself a better human. I am grateful for all the mentor ship opportunities I have received, free professional development events, access to diverse communities, fantastic professors and fellow peers. 
4. General Education
InhibitFactor:
1. Exclusivity : The exclusive nature of certain campus groups can sometimes be an impediment in the way of more equitable extension of opportunities. 
2. Poor lecturing : I have strongly disliked over 4 classes at UCLA (with most of them being in the Stats department). Instructors that fail to communicate the core concepts make the class experience an absolutely dreadful one. It is really hard to sit through theoretical classes with professors that lack essential communication skills, and as much as I respect and value the role of a professor, it nevertheless makes it a frsutrating experience. 
3. Large Size of UCLA makes it hard to experience a lot of things

In addition to this, my family cannot support my education or living expenses because they have their own expenses. I commute on a daily basis from a pretty far city and this makes me feel more excluded because I do not have as much access to the campus and community as much as other students. I also fund my own education by working a valet job to cover what I need for school and other expenses. I am always tired from work and my commute, but I still have to find the time and energy to study and complete assignments.

HelpFactor: I think office hours and practice problems have helped me succeed academically, but I feel I struggle socially and emotionally.
InhibitFactor: The course load makes it a struggle to succeed emotionally because of the stress, as well as factors like over-enrollment and difficulty with tests. People also seem to be more closed off because they focus on academics which can make it hard to succeed socially.

HelpFactor: Friends with a similar mentality, my own hard work
InhibitFactor: Staying away from home and family is stressful

HelpFactor: Be part of as many student organizations as possible. I am a junior transfer from another UC and there are not many people like that. I am also busy recruiting for Summer Internship and hence I do not really have time to socialize. Will probably feel a greater sense of belonging to UCLA after finding a job.
InhibitFactor: Recruiting which takes up 90% of the time. Rather than difficulty of classes, I simply do not really have time to study. It's a trade off that I made.

HelpFactor: Research

I play on a sports team here, so i feel like I have a lot of friends within the athletic community that want me to succeed and are supportive of me. My high school definitely prepared me academically, and my family is so supportive and there for me always.
InhibitFactor: I do have anxiety, and I definitely get anxiety when it comes to school and academic success. I feel like not a lot of athletes are taking the same heavy courseload that I am. None of my friends are my major/minor, so in this sense I do feel like I don't have very many friends at all in my classes, and sometimes I feel like no one in these classes can truly understand what my schedule is like and the time commitments I take to be an athlete in season full time and take a full courseload of classes. This does give me a lot of stress and sometimes i feel overwhelmed and lack belief in my own abilities. I study on my own, do my work on my own, and I kind of bear all my problems on my own.

HelpFactor: I think that academically, having a good support system has been very helpful. I feel like having a tight knit group of friends has been beneficial from an emotional and emotional stand point, and this in turn has helped me academically.
InhibitFactor: The largest hindrance that I have faced while at UCLA is maintaining financial stability. I get enough money to pay for tuition, but I have to pay for a part of housing on my own. Therefore, I have to work about 20 hours a week to make enough to cover all my expenses.  I think that keeping up with my work schedule and the demands of school has been the most challenging part of attending UCLA. Often times, I find that at least one aspects of my life has to suffer in order for me to have enough time to work.

HelpFactor: My friends have helped me succeed at UCLA more so than anything or anyone else. Whether it be homework, roommate problems, or issues with other friends, they're always there to assist and give good advice. Most recently, I had an issue with my old roommate who owed me quite a bit of money and was very disrespectful to me. I asked my friends around me for suggestions on how to confront her, and they were able to keep me calm and focused in figuring out what to say and how to say it to resolve the situation. As for my academics, I've been able to make some friends in my classes, so now we have a study group for help on homework assignments and exam prep. Because I'm an introvert, it's harder for me to go out and socialize, but my friends always try to drag me out with them so I don't stay cooped up at home all the time; they keep me in check.
InhibitFactor: The biggest inhibiting factor to my success at UCLA is not getting enough sleep and financial burdens. A big reason why I'm not getting enough sleep is because my current roommate snores and I'm a very light sleeper, and living in the apartments close to busy streets isn't helping with all the ambulances, firetrucks, and honking from daily traffic. If I was more financially stable, I believe my studies and social life would be much better off than they currently are. I would be able to purchase better resources for studying, and I could have a better social life when going out with friends.

HelpFactor: Identify the things that you want to fulfillment the most during the college life, and properly assign time based on your goals. You can be successful in most of the things if you spend time on those, but the problem is how much time to spend on each when you only have limited energy and time.

HelpFactor: My strong work ethic, ambition, goal-driven state of mind is what made me succeed academically up until now. The support from my friends and family is what help me succeed emotionally and socially.
InhibitFactor: Finances and access to resources inhibit my success from a young age. Finances stopped me from taking outside tutoring classes, sports, and art lessons. I didn't have a lot of resources and people to take advice from in my childhood so I learned a lot of things by myself. Things like what classes to take in school or what subject to focus on so I can succeed in college. If I knew from a young age, I would have done more sports or started taking classes/workshops in computer programming instead of doing art.

HelpFactor:
My parents sent me to summer school up until high school, which helped me become a better student and retain/process information better. My involvement in Key Club from sophomore to senior year, including being vice president, trained me to handle leadership roles, logistics, and social skills, and it helped me develop a close group of friends back home. 
Similarly, I've developed a support network here by being a part of VSU Modern and VSU-related events like Vietnamese Culture Night (VCN) and Southeast Asian Admit (SEA Admit). My first year, I had a counselor from SEA CLEAR who gave me further advice and support.
InhibitFactor: I struggle to make close friends at UCLA, even now, despite being involved in different organizations. I'm disinterested in joining different organizations even though I have a slight desire to expand my network and work on career development. Long hours of practice have constrained my time to focus on academics and sleep, but I still did well in my classes.

HelpFactor: My family has definitely helped me with my success here at UCLA. I run things by my parents to get their opinion on what classes will be helpful outside of college. The friends in my major classes have also been very helpful for studying.
InhibitFactor: The way that the classes are offered is very, very stressful. Only offering a course once a year makes it very difficult to get in, or can create stress about making sure to be on the path to take that class at the right time, otherwise you will graduate two quarters later than anticipated. Some of the teachers at UCLA don't seem as accessible as others, perhaps due to class size.

Being a Christian, I have much fellowship with different Christians and can rely on them, the Bible, and the Lord to help me through the trials. Therefore, I work hard, I study hard, I pray, and do whatever I can to succeed in UCLA.
InhibitFactor: Not having enough time to work out at the gym has hindered my health. Being overwhelmed with all the requirements to be a pre-med student as well.

HelpFactor: First of all, professors in UCLA are at a very high level, which helps me to learn and succeed academically. Besides, UCLA held a lot of events. Participating in the events, I make a lot of friends, which makes me succeed socially. What's more, UCLA is a big family, we are all bruins. As a international student, I would feel homesick sometimes, but UCLA makes me feel at home.
InhibitFactor: I think everything is great at UCLA. But  the tuition for international students is a little bit expensive, we need to pay 15000 dollors per quarter.

HelpFactor:
I think it was extremely important to live on campus during my first two years at UCLA. I really enjoyed the experience that I had living in close proximity with my friends and I think I really grew as a person at UCLA - especially socially. My home is about 1 hour away from UCLA, so I had the choice to commute and at first my parents wanted me to commute. I ultimately decided to dorm so I can focus on my studies instead, and I think it was the best decision I've made. 
My brother and sister went to Cal Poly Pomona during their 4 years in college and it was only 15 minutes away from home so they commuted. They had a completely different experience there, and I think the difference was mainly because UCLA has a great culture and I was able to take advantage of this by living at UCLA. I was really able to focus on growing myself academically and socially. In terms of success emotionally, I don't know how I may have grown in that aspect.
InhibitFactor: The main thing that inhibited my "success" (or more like success in growth) at UCLA was always having to worry about my grades. I came into UCLA as a pre-med, and I knew that med schools looked at high GPAs very favorably over lower GPAs so I was always worried about my grades and thus I would just take classes to get the grade and not for the fun of learning. But starting mid-third year, I left the pre-med track and began exploring my own interests by taking classes I've always been interested in. I felt a lot happier since I don't worry about my GPA as much anymore, but I still feel like I can't learn just for the fun of it because there's always the pressure of getting a good grade in class. The stress of wanting to get a good grade somehow inhibits me from learning.

HelpFactor: Getting involved in clubs and internships, going to class, and trying my best in general.

HelpFactor:
I think there are two main things that have made me successful at UCLA. The first is sports. I love sports, and watching, attending, and playing sports is my favorite time away from my studies. I think this time keeps me going. It is also where I have met many friends.

The other is my competitiveness. I like the competition that I am faced with at UCLA, and I think it is the reason I am successful in my classes.
InhibitFactor: Disliking classes. Some of the classes I had to take freshman and sophomore year were not my favorite, and I think they lead to me struggling more in them, and not being in the best mood.

HelpFactor: First off, going to college is something that people should be more proud of and be recognized. I think that having that confidence is important but at the same time acknowledging that college expectations of academics is different. You need to be able to mange yourself and your time to match what you expect of yourself. Some people have different standards and that's okay but as long as they allow themselves to understand those I think it is important to hold yourself accountable in all areas of college life.
InhibitFactor: Lack of transfer of credit, lack of availability of college counselors besides CAC if you are not an honor, first gen etc. High variability in type of teaching styles of professor that invalidate the knowledge of how you understand because you don't understand their tests and way of teaching

HelpFactor: Having supportive roommates to come home help me after a long day of classes. They have helped me academically, socially, and emotionally. The alleviation of college tuition and expenses help with the academic aspect of UCLA because I do not need to worry too much about money problems and living expenses along with school.
InhibitFactor: The social expectation to be involved in campus orgs and clubs can be detrimental to emotional health. Because so many pre-health and well-established clubs have application processes, I experienced many rejections my first year at UCLA. It was emotionally and socially draining to constantly be met with rejection. Along with this, some clubs can be very centralized, meaning there is established expectations for their members and it was easy for me to feel socially outcast because I did not fit in. Overall, it was difficult to find my own niche at UCLA. I do think this is individual experience and others may or may not resonate with this.

I also don't have a car so I don't often leave the Westwood area and I sometimes feel like I'm trapped in the UCLA area.

HighGPA: NA

HelpFactor: One thing that has really helped me is the friends and specific relationships I've made with other people. For example, last year, I struggled with my physical health for a large majority of the school year, and I visited many doctors who could not diagnose what was wrong with me. Eventually, they found a parasitic infection inside of me that was affecting my thyroid function, leading to my symptoms. This took a large toll on me, as it took about 3-6 months for the whole situation to finally be under control. Since I'm out of state and far from home, this was very difficult to deal with on my own, but I had my friends with me to talk to. Even though we had just recently met, I was privileged to be able to tell them how I was feeling about the whole situation. They're also just a great resource in general, because when I have classes with them, it's easier to study and learn the material.
InhibitFactor: Obviously, my health has been an inhibitor to my success, as I detail above. Because of my situation last year, it was very difficult for me to get involved at UCLA and to do well academically. While I received a 4.0 during fall and spring quarters, my health declined during winter quarter and led to subpar performance during that quarter. This eclipse of my academic potential led to emotional stress and declining mental health, but since then, I've accepted what has happened and have concluded that I can't change the past, I can only move forward and rectify it.

HelpFactor: My friend help me a lot to overcome challenges
InhibitFactor: UCLA have too many people, and the opportunities are limited

HelpFactor: Academically I would say going to office hours helps out a ton for success. A lot of teachers are actually very approachable and want students to succeed so going to visit them when they did not have to deal with every student in their lecture helped. Socially I joined a fraternity my freshman year which helped me make friends and get to meet people from a wide variety of places who are studying a wide variety of majors. It definitely helped me grow and learn to be accepting of all types of people and that everybody is generally very nice once you get to talk to them.
InhibitFactor: Academically, I feel like large classes inhibited my success. It can be very intimidating to be in such large lectures especially early on as a freshman and sophomore. Once I got into smaller, more specific classes for my major and minor I found that learning and getting to understand the material. I would say also not getting to know other people in my classes didn't help. When a lot of the work is individual and you don't know people the classes can be very difficult. However, when you have to do group projects it lets you make friends and have someone to talk to in the future about projects and homework.

HelpFactor: Discussions have generally been very helpful academically, especially discussions for the Math 30 series. Review sessions by TAs and profs have also been helpful. Socially, joining clubs has been a helpful experience. I have liked joining clubs with a variety of purposes; I am in a club that tutors underserved communities, the Daily Bruin, and a purely social club, which cater to my different academic, social, and emotional needs. Reslife social events have also been helping in socializing.
InhibitFactor: Some factors that have inhibited my success are the large class sizes and somewhat brutal class distributions for some classes. Another factor is just that everyone at UCLA is very high-achieving and seems to be involved in so many things at a time: i.e. it seems like the typical student at UCLA takes 18 units, has a job, is in a leadership position in three clubs, has an internship and a summer internship lined up, and can still make time to socialize. This can put a lot of pressure on me to feel like I need to be "keeping up" with other students rather than prioritizing my mental and emotional health. I highly recommend that students not compare themselves to others and do exactly what they need to do to live happy and fulfilling lives.

HelpFactor: I feel that going to office hours and doing homework have helped me succeed academically, as well as taking care of my physical health has helped me immensely. The welcoming faculty and the initiative that UCLA takes to try and helps its students have really helped me get to where I am.
InhibitFactor: Not seeking help for mental health issues such as overwhelming anxiety have definitely inhibited my emotional well being over here. Campus culture is also very rushed, everyone wants to get everything done even if it kills them, and I buy into it. Not putting myself out there because I was too attached to home has stunted me from forming any lasting friendships so far.

HelpFactor: Having a group of friends in the same major (or at least who take similar classes) is very helpful in succeeding at UCLA, simply because we can work together and accomplish things that might be very challenging otherwise. For instance, I can ask someone who has taken a class I'm currently enrolled in for advice when dealing with a tricky homework assignment or understanding a difficult concept. Having same-class peers also makes it is easy to study in groups, which is one of the most productive ways to prepare for an exam, at least from my experience.
InhibitFactor: I would say that lack of interest is my greatest inhibiting factor at UCLA. If I'm not interested in the material, I tend to slack when it comes to paying attention in class, studying for exams, turning in homework assignments, etc.

HelpFactor: I think being able to find ways to destress has been very important. It is very important to find times for my own relaxation and to check up on my mental health. I accomplish this by doing yoga and exercising. Also, some nights I have recognized that I can't study and need a break. In addition, having friends to study with and support me has made it a lot easier to be successful. We are all going through similar things and can pick each other up.

HelpFactor: The depression and pressure from academic as well as social life at UCLA somewhat helped me to keep going forward. Although it is toxic for mental health, it pushes people to the point that we have to step outside of our shells and throw ourselves into a tremendous ocean where life is prosperous but also full of hardships. Just by looking at other people who are successful at UCLA, I feel the needs to learn and improve myself everyday.
InhibitFactor: Money, time, tough (unnecessary) curriculum, limited services, unstable emotions due to grades and rejection letters, the "adult culture" in which everyone tries to look professional, mature, and successful, but forget that we are all human and just create more anxieties for ourselves. There is a lack of genuine communication and mutual understanding between human. Other stressful factors are fake manners, attitudes towards each other, and those "masks" that we are wearing. If we are hungry, cut the apple and share. Only giving the apple to someone who can evaluate the color, the shape, and the vitamins is not very ideal.

Major: Human Biology and Society and Communication
HelpFactor: The support of my family, seeing my psychiatrist, being in a community of people that makes UCLA feel smaller, finding majors I am interested in, and making sure to plan ahead for school work. My abroad physics program to Australia was the highlight of my time at UCLA and students should be encouraged to study abroad as well as the school should develop more programs and fix the ones they have.
InhibitFactor: The cost of living makes anything difficult to enjoy. The professors and TA's at UCLA that I have experienced tend to treat students like we are incompetent. I often experience condescending treatment. I feel that the school often does not listen to student feedback. For example, a Comm TA in the psychology program made me cry and I discussed it with the professor who did nothing about it. Also, the LS department has serious issues that does not accurately assess student understanding of material yet despite student complaints, there is no change. There are so many roadblocks like I cannot enroll in classes for my major until I declare double major but they do not even offer the classes I need to take. There are not enough seats for students that need classes. There are supposedly "tons" of clubs to join but I apply to 12 clubs and don't get into any when I don't think there is anything wrong with me.

HelpFactor: I think the factor that help me is the passion with the subject I am studying and the support of my family.

HelpFactor: Academically, I used to not do so well when I first got into college. Definitely after my first quarter, I learned study tactics and a lotting time to study. For example, in high school I would rarely study and manage my time well as academics during high school came easy to me. This translated into college and I quickly found out that it does not work that way. After the learning experience of not doing so well in my classes, I began to set time to study like studying at least a week and half before a test and also to manage my time wisely. Socially came very easy for me. Emotionally however, I began to draw back from social life and it was not easy being independent. I still deal with this, however occupying yourself with hobbies is a nice way of dealing with this.
InhibitFactor: The factors that helped me cope with academics and my social life, were listening to podcast on time management and the importance of getting things done. This distracted me from the negative thoughts and depressed state of mind I had whenever I did bad on a test or felt lonely.

HelpFactor: I am very happy that UCLA does offer flexibility to students. My major was Economics when I got into UCLA, but dream of my academic major has always been Statistics. I just could not apply to stats major by the time I transferred. UCLA did not set strict boundaries and say: you MUST stay in your original major.. they did listen to what I want, did help me to get back to undeclared first and finally jumped Into the major I truly want to be in. It was not an easy process because of the requirement of excellent grades in certain classes, but at least the school does offer a possibility of change my major.. This is the most thankful event happened my time at UCLA
InhibitFactor: There is limit source of tutoring at school. STEM major is very hard to finish and it gave me depression sometimes. UCLA only offers office hour of professor, TA, and some random tutoring ( pay is high) . they don't have any tutoring center or anything, I feel like I have to survive in hard classes by myself.

HelpFactor: I am in multiple groups for underrepresented minorities in STEM that provide tutoring .

HelpFactor: By myself and also special thanks to Dr.Peterson's guidance

HelpFactor: The people I've met are very humble and kind. There are also many academic resources that can help me figure out information about my major and opportunities. InhibitFactor: Sometimes depending on my class schedules or exams, it feels like I am suffocated and don't have time to finish everything. These periods don't last longer than a week though.

HelpFactor: Having roommates that also major in STEM are a great help emotionally. We often talk about academically related subjects or bond over common struggles and failures. Going to office hours has also been a big factor in my success in certain classes.
InhibitFactor: The grading system has been inhibiting to my personal academic success at UCLA. Rather than striving to intuitively understand material, I am often pushed to study for tests and assignments rather than explore different aspects of the topic or work on independent projects. As a result, I may receive a decent grade in the course but not have many long term takeaways from it.

InhibitFactor: I feel like I tend to overstress myself and worry too much about my grades at times. I want to do well in my classes so badly that it causes me to have some pretty bad anxiety when it comes to studying for tests or juggling a bunch of deadlines.

HelpFactor:
I have been able to get accommodations for my mental health condition, which included a specific living situation on campus as well as occasional extensions for school assignments. This greatly helped me still be able to succeed academically during a time when I was struggling. 

The support of my parents has helped succeed in every way possible at UCLA. I have parents who support my mental health and my education. I am fortunate enough that they can also pay my full college tuition. They are a huge factor in my success here. 

Personal motivation has also been an important factor for success at UCLA. It is such a large campus community that it is easy to just feel like a number, sort of unimportant. One of the biggest things I learned was the need to self-advocate, to speak up for help and opportunities, and to actively participate in groups on campus. This has helped me feel like I belong at UCLA.
InhibitFactor:
Something specific that I feel has inhibited the success I wanted to have at UCLA has been trying to find undergraduate research experiences in the sciences. As a freshman, I applied to the biomedical research minor after earning an A+ in the preparatory course. I had a 3.9 GPA at the time. I was interviewed but was rejected. I applied twice more after this, and was still rejected. When I asked what could be done to improve my application, I was given generic answers. There was not really a clear explanation for my not getting accepted, despite limited lab space. After this, I struggled to find independent research opportunities with other professors. I tried cold emailing, and talking with professors in office hours. At one point in my junior year, I spoke to a professor about his lab and he said that he would rather accept freshmen because they have more years to spend in the lab, which would make training them worth it. I explained that I had wanted to start research as a freshmen but had struggled to find opportunities. I developed a great relationship with a professor who was not actively doing research, but who recommended me to several of his colleagues, but I was still not able to find an opportunity. I am now in my fourth year. I am disappointed, because I chose UCLA partly because of its reputation for incredible research. I even reached out to the chair of my major department, asking for feedback or advice on finding lab research opportunities, but was not told any information I did not already know or had not already tried. I just feel there was never an answer as to why I was not accepted into the minor, and since then, the challenge of finding a research opportunity has taken a toll on me. 

Personally, mental health issues have been a challenge for me throughout my life, and this continued into college and potentially negatively impacted my academics. However, I felt there were resources available to me that were helpful at UCLA.

HelpFactor: I always go to class, take neat notes, and finish homework on time. I work hard for my classes. I have a lot of emotional support from the one that I love and the one that loves me.

HelpFactor: My friends and I always help each other in anything. They encourage me and remind me that I belong here at UCLA. My family understands that it takes a lot of work to be at this school. I considered taking a break, but it was my parents that got me back on my feet to try the class again the following quarter. They understood that UCLA can be a challenge and told me that there is no shame in me falling, but I need to be able to pick myself back up. My brother is the one who always takes my mind off of school and helps me enjoy life. The counselors at Murphy Hall and Statistics faculty help me academically.
InhibitFactor: I would say myself. Before, I was introverted and afraid to talk to the professors and TA's for help. I feel like I am more open to get help when I need it now.

As a nontraditional student, I feel that I began my undergraduate studies with specific goals and vision in mind. I feel incredibly privileged to be a financial aid recipient, which has allowed me to spend my time focused on my academic studies and extracurricular activities relevant to my future career interests. I have also been fortunate to have met like-minded and collaborative peers, who I am greatly indebted to for the endless study sessions and support throughout my undergraduate career. I have been lucky to be mentored by incredible graduate students, faculty, and researchers at the bleeding-edge of their fields.

HighGPA: NA

HelpFactor: Professors and TAs should care about students' efforts and create a comfortable and welcomed environment to give students confidence and opportunities for improvement.
InhibitFactor: Professors and TAs should not ignore the efforts and needs of students. The Stats 20 taken this quarter is a very disappointing lesson. Basically, the professor and TAs are reluctant to respond to students' private questions on emails, and many public questions asked on Campuswire are answered by students themselves. The grading of homework and exam is ridiculously harsh, and the professor simply replied to students that "students should not care much about the grades" without giving any detailed rubric in advance for letting student make remedies in the next assignment. Suggestions to the faculty of Stats 20 in Fall 2019 are: 1. Give detailed rubric and explanations in every assignment; 2. Professor or TAs should explain homework after grading in order to prevent students from making the same mistake again; 3. Professor and TAs should be responsive to students' questions within a guaranteed time limit (e.g. 24/48 hours at latest); 4. Professor should assign letter grades base on percentile/ranking instead of absolute grade, and the assignment grades should be curved and then averaged in calculating the final grade instead of being averaged and then curved (this will undermine the difference on distribution of each assignment).

HelpFactor: My own perseverance and confidence; Friends I knew before matriculating to UCLA.
InhibitFactor: My disposition to seek help only when necessary, which potentially lost some valuable chances; I am not a good improviser, so I find myself uncomfortable in some social occasions.

HelpFactor: Having a positive mindset, ability to quickly adjust to new environments, and willingness to step out of the comfort zone, and proper time management are very important.

academically: preview, review, discussion, use office hour, if you have any questions ask professor, TA, or your friends ASAP. Never leave too much stuff to the next day.

GPA: NA
HelpFactor: I strongly believe my friends are one of the factors. Academic challenge is not only for me, but also all my friends struggle and study together, which really encourages and motivates me.
InhibitFactor: Academic workload and competition inhibited. It is stressful that I need to compete with my peers for better grades, and I sometimes feel depressed when getting unexpectedly lower grades than my peers.

HelpFactor: I think joining club volleyball has been the greatest factor of my success here at UCLA. I joined the club my first week of freshman year and it immediately gave me a group of friends, a consistent schedule and consistent exercise. Although it takes up a lot of my time especially when I have a lot of work, I need the mental break from my school work. It has given me a community within UCLA. I have now become the president of the club and have become very involved in club sports which has allowed me to me to meet so many different people.
InhibitFactor: I think the competitive nature of UCLA has really inhibited my success academically, socially and emotionally. Especially in STEM classes, many teachers stress how the class is graded on a curve and you are competing against all of your classmates. I think this really discourages social interactions and teamwork in classes. I have also found that not just classes, but also clubs are very competitive on campus. I know my club volleyball team has to cut about 80 girls who tryout every year because the school is so big. I have applied to numerous clubs and was asked to submit a resume or interview. I have been rejected by a number of clubs which is really discouraging. People always say to join clubs to meet more people and find your community, but at UCLA I have found this very difficult. Its hard to meet new people when you constantly get rejected from clubs and it makes me less likely to reach out in the future.

HelpFactor: The amount of study space
InhibitFactor: The lack of mentorship

HelpFactor:
Like-minded peers- When I am surrounded by people who are motivated to succeed, I would try harder to succeed.
Be open minded- Being an open minded person alleviates a lot of emotional and social stress.
Doing something I truly enjoy- Ever since I joined a dance team here at UCLA, I found myself so much happier than freshman year. I don't necessarily make more friends, but having a safe escape in my life helped me so much.
InhibitFactor:
self-discipline- Sometimes, it's hard to bring myself to work when I am suppose to. I can get distracted and slack off easily. I don't have enough discipline to follow an efficient and regular schedule. 
consistent motivation- I think I lack consistent motivation, which is the driving force behind my studying. It's so easy to get caught up in all the school works, activities, and other life issues which caused me to lose sight of the bigger purpose and have my efficiency deteriorated.

They provide a lot of academic help and support related to school/job hunting. I'm also in a professional fraternity that provides a great support system because we are taught to be empathetic, and a great network for learning about job opportunities or just events happening.
InhibitFactor: I had poor study habits during the first two years of college. Even though people and programs market themselves as being capable of giving support, I still didn't know who to reach out to and who to get advice from. Kinda had to navigate on my own and learn from my mistakes, rather doing things right on the first try.

HelpFactor: It took a long time, but understanding what study methods are most effective for me. I also grew to be unafraid to ask questions or reach out for help. I used to be embarrassed to ask questions because I thought it would make me look dumb, but now I don't really care. I found out I really like teaching so I think doing things like the LA program was something that helped me out as a student from an academic and emotional perspective.
InhibitFactor:
I think that I definitely experience a lot of imposter syndrome at UCLA. I never knew people when to SAT bootcamps or all those kinds of things to get into UCLA. There is a lot of economic diversity here, but growing up most of my friends didn't have a car, go to Europe, or any of the things that a lot of people here seem to have experiences with. Essentially most of the people I meet don't really have much in common with me from a background perspective so it's hard to feel like I belong when my life has been completely different from a social, economic, and ethnic-composition perspective. 
A lot of people generalize the "premed" process to be brutal and that you need a very well-rounded resume.  It has been really hard with all this pressure as a premed to do research, volunteering, extracurriculars for your resume to med school. I feel so burnt out already and I haven't even applied yet. I applied to several clubs as a sophomore and I got rejected from almost every single one. It's really hard to keep your thoughts positive when you aren't able to gain any experience in a field that is essentially mandatory for you resume. I think that as I get older my time to socialize and be essentially a person is almost zero to none because of the demands of the career I want to pursue.

HelpFactor: Having small classes has helped me because I can ask the professor for help more often. I also have a good TA this quarter for math who is very helpful. Being friends with my roommates has helped me socially and emotionally by having people to do fun activities with and talk to about the stress.
InhibitFactor: This quarter, my math class is taught by a professor who was a child prodigy. He goes over material very quickly and doesn't explain many concepts and examples because he assumes we will understand them as easily as he does. We also don't have a textbook for the course making it very hard to try and teach myself the material. Socially, I sometimes feel like there is not a strong sense of community in and outside of classes. (This might just be for south campus classes where there is a lot of competition.) So when I fail or do poorly on an exam, I feel like I am the only one even though there are probably more people like me. I  feel like everyone else is smarter than me. This creates a lot of my stress and makes me feel like I don't really belong here.

They are always there for me and give great advice, so I feel comforted because of that. I had a midterm in my first year where I was very scared. Calling my parents really helped me to calm down and relax.
InhibitFactor: Being away from my family was hard at first. In my first year, it was tough because it was a time where I wasn't ready to be away from my family. Now that I am older, it is much better now. It is all about the growing up and maturing process.

HelpFactor: Going to office hours have helped me succeed, especially when the professor is engaging and does not favor students. I feel excluded when professors tend to assume people come to help just to get recommendation letters, because I don't like that environment of competitiveness. I also like that classes are very collaborative. I've learned to prioritize my own self health and spend time alone cooking, listening to music, and reading a lot.
InhibitFactor: I often feel isolated at UCLA, because I am very introverted and it's hard to meet people. Sometimes it can really feel competitive in classes, when people don't want to share notes or they compete for grades. I distance myself a lot from those people, which helps. I also have anxiety and it's hard to feel like your self health matters in classes where professors assume that their class should be your number one priority. I feel often like I have to put my academic life before my own health in order to do well.

HelpFactor: Going through hardships. I grew up with a pretty sheltered life, where all I had to worry about was my grades, and any stressful factors for me stemmed purely from schoolwork. However, having experienced being an adult, and juggling schoolwork with  other things, such as dating, being social, and taking care of my health, it caused me to face hardships in multiple areas outside of just academics, which have ultimately made me into a better person overall.

In terms of relationships and friends, I will take care of others while not wronging myself, so that I can reduce my psychological burden.

classes are too big, not too much connection between prof and the students.
