HelpFactor: Having friends in the same classes, approachable faculty members that genuinely want to help me learn the material, going to different events on campus for fun (sports, movie screenings, etc.)
My teammates/ friends have helped me get through a lot emotional/academic setbacks.
InhibitFactor: Athletics can be very overwhelming. Coaches can be a big part of any anxiety I have. I'm also tired often, making it harder to get work done.

HelpFactor: Academically, I always try my hardest in the classes I am taking and try to catch myself when I let myself slack off. I always make sure that I have my academic success as a priority before planning other events/activities, unless they are absolutely necessary. Socially, I try to meet new people and open myself up more to build strong friendships. Emotionally, I talk a lot to my parents and close friends whenever I need advice on certain matters or if I need help in any area.
InhibitFactor: Academically, I think I could benefit more if more office hours were held online where students who cannot physically come to office hours can still listen in and ask questions. Emotionally, maybe we can have more destress activities throughout the schoolyear. Nothing socially comes to mind.

HelpFactor: I struggled my first year to make friends. I'm shy and I didn't put myself out there in the beginning and it made things difficult for the rest of the year. I had a poor relationship with my roommates and I felt alone so I put all of my time into my academics and learned what it takes to get decent grades at UCLA. In that sense, not having a social life was nice because I did not get distracted. I had a few acquaintances from classes, and that helped me not feel completely alone and in my opinion saved me from depression. Towards the end of my first year at UCLA I joined a group here on campus in an effort to put myself out there and it was not bad. I dreaded going back to UCLA for my second year. Luckily, my new roommates became my best friends here at UCLA. I suddenly had people who I could rely on and be myself around. That changed everything. I wasn't at school to get a degree, I was at school and I enjoyed the process. My roommates and I share the same future goals so I made my roommates join the group I joined at the end of my first year. We had lots of fun with the group during our second year, got super involved, and we're now officers in that group. My roommates and I are also always there for each other with academic support and advice about things in general. I've grown so much since my first year it's crazy. I am now much more confident in myself and my future goals and I am much more happy and everything is cool. I feel like I might appreciate it more because I struggled in the beginning.
InhibitFactor: During my first year I worked eighteen hours a week to support myself financially. These hours could have been spent for classes. The cost of UCLA is a challenge.

HelpFactor: Having roommates that you can talk to and joke around. Also making sure to be on top of my work and getting enough sleep help me feel less anxious. I also personally believe that doing well on exams is not everything about life, so I tend to not worry so much about my grades.
Joining clubs and organizations where you could meet nice people and make friends. They make UCLA feel a lot smaller and make college much more enjoyable than just doing nothing by myself.
InhibitFactor: I feel that I have not had the necessary foundational study skills to succeed in a collegiate environment developed in high school. My study skills and proclivity for procrastination has had a detrimental effect on my grades and mental well being.

HelpFactor: One factor that helped me succeed socially is forcing myself to join clubs I had mild interests in as a first year. It helped me find friends and a really good support system that supports me academically, socially, and emotionally. Having supportive friends helps my mental health, which helps me the best I can when it comes to academics. A factor that helped me with academics is changing my mindset about learning and learning how to study. Last year, I definitely struggled a lot academically and I developed grit and perseverance that helped me emerge as a better person especially after being beat down like that. The final most important change I made this year was prioritizing my health, because by prioritizing my health I am able to manage my time better so that I am still able to sleep while getting work done.
InhibitFactor: A factor that has inhibited my academic success is an inconsistent work ethic. Sometimes I can work throughout the week really well, but skip one day of studying and it puts me behind again. Another factor is my mental health. On some days, it is very bad and I don't have the motivation or energy to focus on my work, so I am not able to do it. It also confers me with a lot of social anxiety so making friends and meeting new people is still very difficult for me. My mental health makes doing certain things feel like a mountain instead of a small hill like its supposed to be for neurotypical people.

HelpFactor: I can attribute my academic success at UCLA to be rooted in my strong foundation from high school. Many of my high school courses readily prepared me to succeed in my UCLA classes. In addition, almost all professors offered office hours, which were useful to go to to ask questions. The LA program has also been a contributing factor in my educational success because the extra practice from their workshops aided in course material mastery. In terms of socially, UCLA is a cornucopia of unlimited activities and events. You will never get bored or not find something to do with friends.
InhibitFactor: I have encountered some instances where the professor was not very good at assessing students through their exams. The exams were pointlessly difficult to the point that the average was 40%. Besides that, UCLA is filled with very capable students, so competition is naturally bound to occur. You have to constantly stay active to make sure you do not fall behind you peers.

HelpFactor: Finding support through different extracurriculars have made my time at UCLA more inviting and enjoyable as opposed to last year where I just went to class and then back to my dorm. Meeting more people also encouraged me to do better and study more through asking questions and forming study groups, so I feel more prepared academically. I also talked a lot to a peer counselor, who helped me navigate imposter syndrome and figure out my place at UCLA.
InhibitFactor: The competitive atmosphere at UCLA is a leading cause of a lot of my anxiety. I feel like I am not good enough for this school since the people around me, especially in my major, always seem so smart and are doing so much more than I will ever have the energy and capacity to do. I also feel discouraged going to office hours with my professors because of this since one time that I went last year, one super smart and advanced student asked so many questions and the professor focused all their attention on the other student so it was hard for me to speak up about my own questions that I feel are "stupid" or more surface level.

HelpFactor: various programs for interns
InhibitFactor: my boyfriend

HelpFactor: The majority of the faculty cares about the well-being and success of their students and are always willing to help. InhibitFactor: It could be discouraging at times when professors put "trick" questions on exams or put contents that were not covered in class because students study for hours over contents covered in lectures and readings from the textbooks, and when professors test students on concepts that were not covered, it feels like our hard work is not going to be paid off.

HelpFactor: UCLA in general is a very inclusive environment. During my freshman year, when I was new to this environment and did not really know anybody, I found it easy to gel with people from my own ethnic background and they helped me a lot in adapting to life at UCLA and made me feel more comfortable in terms of socializing and overall happiness.
InhibitFactor: Sometimes I find that the large classroom sizes tend to make everyone in the room seem alien to one another. In smaller classrooms it is much easier to gel with and make friends. That is why I feel like during my freshman and sophomore years I did not get to interact with too many people who took the same classes as I did. However, during my junior and senior year I felt like I have gotten to know far more people in my major and forming teams and doing group work has definitely solidified that frienship.

HelpFactor: Having a high GPA at high school and graduating as Valedictorian made me overlook the importance of being honest with myself and seeking help when needed. I was egotistical and wanted to prove that I could do much better than other students, so I took extra courses very often. The result - a low GPA and further pressure to prove that I was not wrong in the beginning. This ended up becoming a very harmful cycle from which I could only escape once I accepted that there is a lot for me to learn and that I have a long way to go to be where I thought I was.
InhibitFactor: Trying to live a college life that would be memorable. I focused more on the now than planning for my future. I focused more on living a happy college life that I did not focus more on things that I could do and learn in the real world even while being a college student.

Some of them are so arrogant when we discuss the project, they do not listen to me and reply my message on group chat sometimes which make me feel really bad. I thought they were smart and good at what we should do for the project at first, but after few weeks, I don't feel they have better skills at all; they do not have much experiences in approaching people from diverse background so make them be not respectful to others just because of the language barriers.

HelpFactor: Mostly my social network. I didn't have that many friends growing up, but now I do and that's what gets me through most of my issues.

HelpFactor: Academically, UCLA did not really help in the sense that it held my hand through the process of leaving a sheltered life provided to me by my parents. I dropped out of UCLA in 2014 and am currently going through the readmission process this Fall. It does feel strange to be 26 and taking classes with 18/19 year olds, but the fact that I had to drop out and learn from my mistakes in order to refocus and reorient myself towards my goals is something that I have learned through my own personal hardships and gives me the motivation to succeed in my current tenure at UCLA. Instead of babying me, the school gave me a lesson in reality. I don't know if UCLA can be faulted or given credit for this, however it took place at UCLA and therefore can be partially attributed to my own failures and subsequent learnings.
InhibitFactor: UCLA is a large school. It can feel like you're not significant when in classes with hundreds of other students and it can often be difficult to make your voice heard. I would not say that this is a huge issue for me, however it was a culture shock due to the fact that I was sent to private schools from 5th grade until I graduated high school, which had extremely small class sizes (<15 kids per class).

HelpFactor: My friends; my boyfriend; my therapist; professors who are kind and understanding; my own determination to succeed; my own willingness to constantly improve myself and make changes to my behavior. The people in my life who are supportive and understanding and mature are the reasons why I am always able to push through difficult times, and that is instrumental in helping me learn and improve and eventually succeed in anything, whether that's school or research or getting leadership positions or even just learning how to be a better friend and girlfriend.  I'm also always willing to get help when I need it, which is why I started going to therapy and why I continue to go--it's made me more self aware, more patient with myself, and less likely to repeat the same mistakes over and over again. Finally, determination is one of my defining traits--it is the word that even people who don't know me very well use to describe me, because my determination to succeed comes through in everything I do. It comes through in how intense and focused I am for lectures, for the leadership roles I hold, even just for conversations with friends.
InhibitFactor: My mental health--when I'm not taking care of myself I have a tendency to lose interest in just about everything; burn out--I tend to take on too much and then burn out, so I'm learning to cut back.

Emotionally: communicating with my friends.
InhibitFactor: taking classes that aren't relevant to my interests but I have to in order to graduate (i.e. Japan 50). Taking classes that I thought would be interesting but turns out they were horrible and I got nothing out of them. Taking classes with horrible professors. Spreading myself too thin: I do a ton of extracurricular activities at UCLA, I intern, and I am a full time student. I am completely drained and my academics are suffering because of it but its my last year to be a college student so I don't want to give up extracurriculars and I need the money so I can't give up my internship. It's really stressful.

GPA: NA
HelpFactor: The most important thing to enter UCLA is that I need to know how to make the best plan to study according to the schedule of each semester. After I go to community college, it's really students themselves making the decision about how much they want to earn as a college student. It's really important to plan the time about preparing for the class, doing the homework, reviewing for the quiz/exams, and your own social life with friends.
InhibitFactor: One of the factor inhibited the success is constancy. Learning is a long process, although you start the class with a really good performance, one mistake you make in the middle might hurt you badly in the course. I have experimence that few times in the past. Starting with a good position and getting loose and then mass up one exam which ended up a heavy pressure on the final to keep the grade up.

HelpFactor: I believe having a supportive friend group that I live with has helped my mental health and performance in academics.
InhibitFactor: My lack of math preparation before coming to UCLA.

HelpFactor: Friends and family.
InhibitFactor: Homesickness and large expenses.

HelpFactor: I would say that confidence is a big factor. Having confidence in whatever you do will lead to you being successful. Also being able to self reflect and correct your mistakes. If you are constantly evaluating yourself, you can adapt to what's working and what isn't
InhibitFactor: Probably just fear. Fear of failing, fear of the perception of others, fear of opening. Just all different types of fear

HelpFactor: Society, environment, and supportive enggagement

The college community on the hill help me get through the first two years pretty easy. Everyday walking around seeing all these students striving for their goals, it motivated me get my work done. Academically, studying with friends helps ease the stress load.
InhibitFactor: The freedom and independence was a major factor for my somewhat downfall. There was a time of lack of motivation overcame my mood accompanied with foolish decisions.

HelpFactor: calm
InhibitFactor: sleep

HelpFactor: My own willpower, study guides from professors, study groups, online office hours
InhibitFactor: applications to join clubs, conflict with class and clubs, 4 midterms in one week, not enough access to professors and research, office hours conflict with classes, overwhelming sense of anxiety about the workload, having to work 12 hours at a job on top of 4 classes, bad scheduling of classes due to administration

HelpFactor: The thing that has helped me succeed the most academically is asking my peers who have taken classes that I am currently in for help. I'm often too nervous or embarrassed to go to office hours so I feel more comfortable asking friends for help.
InhibitFactor: I struggled a lot with depression and other mental health problems during my first year two years at UCLA which hindered my academic success significantly. I found it difficult to seek any sort of professional help as I don't have UCSHIP and my provider is quite far from UCLA.

HelpFactor: #NAME?
InhibitFactor: #NAME?

HelpFactor:
I think have professors who really care about students was instrumental to my success here at UCLA. One example is a professor in the stats department, Christou, who holds office hours almost everyday of the week. Despite being one of my most challenging courses at UCLA, he almost made me feel I could succeed. I think after experiencing such a course, I felt much more confident academically; knowing that I was capable, and knowing all it took was having someone to support you motivated me to continue working hard despite have past rough academic quarters. 
Socially and emotionally, I think joining clubs and pushing myself to meet new people on my floor helped a lot. During more challenging and depressive mental periods, I used the CAPS resource center, which helped a bit as well.
InhibitFactor:
I felt like it was difficult to get involved when I first transferred in. Many organizations are very competitive, and as a result, I feel that many students can struggle to find a place they belong, or acquire access to some of the campuses best resources.  The answer to this problem was to just keep applying, but even then, a student can lose access to valuable resources some clubs tend to have. I think this furthers the notion that a student at a public university is on his/her own, and a result, fostering a more competitive environment. 

Academically, I was always frustrated with discussion and office hours. While some professors/classes put a great emphasis on helping their students, other classes have hundreds of students waiting 20 minutes to ask a professor or TA a question. This can be frustrating, and makes learning much more inefficient. However, I understand that this is a simply drawback to attending a huge public school.

HelpFactor: Self maturity
InhibitFactor: High self-conscious and low self-confidence

HelpFactor: Attending office hours has helped me academically and has allowed me to make a connection with my Professor's at UCLA. Emotionally, I have felt better and more welcomed at UCLA through my social relationships with friends.
InhibitFactor: the vibe on campus can sometimes be uninviting

HelpFactor: The facts
InhibitFactor: The quarter system and the dynamic nature of it- the people in my classes and dorms keep switching which makes it harder to maintain friendships in the long run and the pace of the quarter system makes it harder to keep up and does not leave a lot of time to focus on oneself. Moreover, it doesn't leave any room for slacking for any reason whatsoever.

HelpFactor: Maintain a good work ethic and strive to do my best under the circumstances i'm under.
InhibitFactor: Lack of opportunities or acceptance for older  non-traditional students.

HelpFactor: Developing good time management skills, s that I could succeed academically but also have time for emotional health and a social life
InhibitFactor: The anxiety about cost of tuition, textbooks, rent, food etc. It is far too high to be reasonable to expect a full time student to handle

HelpFactor: I became involved with a Christian fellowship on campus and found people that were so willing to go out of their way to care for me. The upperclassmen invited me over to study and made home-cooked meals for me, and others helped me with my first college chemistry and mathematics classes. I had friends to eat with at almost every dining hall meal, and I planned meet ups with them to get to know them individually. I also joined a small group Bible study, and the girls there became some of my closest friends.
InhibitFactor: My mom has chronic arm and wrist pain from working, and my dog currently has a brain tumor (he is going to pass away soon). Things at home have been stressful, and I wish I could be at home to help with the situation. Also, my first year, I was very homesick and thought about home all of the time. I was also overwhelmed at all of the successful people here, and I felt pressure to be like them.

HelpFactor: Joining clubs, like swipe out hunger at ucla, helped me find a smaller group of people in which people had similar interests as me. Also, finding friends in office hours who had similar coursework as me was helpful.
InhibitFactor: Classes that are intentionally difficult or have curve cutoffs are bad for my self confidence.

HelpFactor: The factors that have helped me succeed academically is that I like to stay on top of my classes and make sure that I understand everything the day that it is taught, which helps me when it's time for an exam. Socially, I'm friends with all my roommates so we do fun things together. Emotionally, I'm still a mess haha.
InhibitFactor: I think that one of the biggest things inhibiting my success emotionally is that I really miss living at home. I don't like los angeles and living here for 4 years is really difficult. In addition, I feel trapped in westwood, since there are few opportunities to go out of the city and everything is so expensive.

HelpFactor: patient
InhibitFactor: the workload and the language

HelpFactor: Sleep and friends
InhibitFactor: Professors that are terrible

HelpFactor: failing, going to OH, having friends in and outside of class, going home on the weekends to de-stress from school
InhibitFactor: not having the guidance and knowledge about finances in college, career choices, grad school, and EC

HighGPA: NA
HelpFactor: Studying with friends always helps me succeed academically; I find that I always do better on exams and in classes when I study alongside someone (even if we're not studying the exact same material), Joining clubs helped me succeed socially and helped me meet new people and interact with them.
InhibitFactor: The workload and stress of keeping my gpa up and doing well in classes and on exams has inhibited my emotional capabilities, and in turn, has led to me not preparing as best as possible and performing even worse on exams.

HelpFactor: meaningful friendships; going home (going away from campus for a break); honest conversations with other students; faculty members who show that they care; new friendships in different classes
InhibitFactor: socioeconomic barriers; first-generation status; disconnect with friends and faculty members between academics and personal life (when many students find UCLA to be not only a school but also a home)

Ethnic: I would prefer not to say
HelpFactor: My friends and family have been the driving force that have helped me succeed at UCLA. Rather than feeling obligated about delivering results, I willingly want to perform well because of them.
InhibitFactor: Large class sizes and professors who do not know how to teach well or speak english are the most critical inhibitors.

HelpFactor: Something that has helped me succeed is having friends in my classes.  It helps having people to turn to for help with the homework or the class in general and it helps knowing that they are going through the same things as you in terms of the class. I think it also helps to surround yourself with people who have similar workloads that you do and people who push/encourage you to put academics first. For example, sometimes it is difficult if you are taking a bunch of classes with heavy workloads and all of your friends are not and so they spend less time doing work and more time going out.  Sometimes it can be difficult saying no to fun activities all the time.
InhibitFactor: Some factors that have greatly inhibited my success at UCLA is having problems with my roommates.  It is extremely important to set boundaries with your friends and to make sure you make your own mental health a priority when it come to friendships and roommates.  Having problems with roommates is super detrimental to success emotionally, socially, and academically and since it occurs in your "home" it can really affect your daily schedule.

HelpFactor: My cultural background as an Asian American student has taught me a lot about resilience and sacrifice and being able to prioritize things above my emotions and surprisingly (and somewhat sadly) my mental health. It's about pushing past the hardship, not succumbing to it.
InhibitFactor: At the same time, my levels of anxiety have strongly increased since coming to school at UCLA. This anxiety, fear of failure and pressure to succeed has increased the amount of panic attacks I've received, major changes in mood and perspective, as well as poor self-image and imposter syndrome.

HelpFactor: The people in my Christian fellowship have become my closest friends and I depend on them academically, socially, emotionally, and spiritually. We study together, hang out together, and are there for each other when we're facing hardships. Being with them reminds myself of my purpose in life and my reason to try my best with everything.
friends, family, ta office hours
InhibitFactor: relationship stress, family events

HighGPA: NA
HelpFactor: As a transfer student, honestly, I was pretty scared during the first quarter here, everything seems overwhelming. Luckily, I found my best friend out of my ethnicity and my english has improved. Also, some of the Professors from my major are very caring and willing to help. UCLA is stressful, but there are a lot of cool and smart people, sometimes I feel insecure because I don't feel as good as them. I'm still trying my best to success and  enjoy my time in UCLA. Overall, I like this school.
My high school focused a lot on writing and I think that the curriculum and teachers set me up to do well at UCLA.
InhibitFactor: I feel like growing up in a predominantly white neighborhood did not prepare me for the diversity I have seen at UCLA. I sometimes feel that there are a lot of strong political opinions that come into the classroom (despite being a neuro major) and I either don't have an opinion or have the "wrong" opinion about it so I just remain quiet and feel really awkward but maybe that's my fault because I didn't grow up in a woke neighborhood. I also feel that growing up in an Asian household where they stigmatize mental health, i was not well-equipped to deal with anxiety amongst other things at UCLA.

HelpFactor: My boyfriend has really helped me succeed and having him believe in me. It's also amazing to have a mix of friends who are achieving at the same level as me and also doing better than me. It's a good mix of feeling like I am normal and proficient while also pushing me to work harder.
InhibitFactor: I think the teachers are absolutely shit at UCLA. There is no care for your emotional well-being at UCLA. And I think in general UCLA does a really great job at not taking care of their students. The classrooms are dirty, the bathrooms smell like a sewer. It sends a real strong message to the students that UCLA doesn't care about their undergraduate population and that all the funding is going into other things like graduate level research and athletics that just bring more money and funding into the school. The academics are not hard at UCLA but trying to complete the academics thrown at you while having the teachers and school in general let you know that you're absolute shit is the hardest part.

HelpFactor: teachers the stress the importance of the well-being of students, teachers that are very passionate about not only their research, but also teaching because it shows in their teaching capabilities, teachers that promote a united class, rather than pitting students against one another.
InhibitFactor: when teachers grade in a way that pits students against one another, teachers that make mastery almost impossible, such that you dont ever feel rewarded for the time and effort you put into classes.

HelpFactor: Throughout life I have been well prepared for college and I feel as though my high school did an adequate job of preparing me for college. Once in college, I was able to succeed by having a supportive family and friend group. I formed a close group of friends within the first week I was at college which I think was very important for my success. I had a strong system of support and never felt alone. Additionally, many of my friends were in similar majors so we had classes together and could help each other.
InhibitFactor: The stress of academics and social stresses of college made it more difficult to succeed. My natural tendency of depression and anxiety made my success at UCLA a bit more difficult.

HelpFactor: Academically, I think my fear of failure has really driven my success. Otherwise I'm not really sure what I can attribute to my success.
InhibitFactor: I think my lack of preparedness for college has inhibited my success at UCLA. For my first year it was really hard to adapt to UCLA which I think has affected me in years since.

HelpFactor: PLFs have helped me greatly academically, my friends have also been a really strong support system I could often lean on.
InhibitFactor: The competitive nature, the lack of communities I am able to join with my low GPA that would help my academic career. The lack of knowledge on available resources

Minor: Environmental Systems and Society; Public Affairs
HelpFactor: Talking to people from other backgrounds so that I can become a more empathetic person.
InhibitFactor: Academic stress that I know stems from a class/assignment that will not help me in the future or contribute to my general knowledge/intelligence.

HelpFactor: Switching majors, made me realize I did not like what I was doing and I have been exploring better niches for myself. Having responsible friends with their lives together also made me get mine together and focus on working instead of sitting around moping.
InhibitFactor: I got a concussion and was going through mental health issues, and the counselors for the economics department were absolute garbage and pretty much no help at all. I had similar experiences with professors. As an incoming freshman I had no idea what I was doing when I came in, but the amount of information or what resources I could use was so overwhelming that I had no idea what to do even if I did want help. I also didn't really accept certain metnal health issues that I had which set me back quite a lot.

HelpFactor: My family and friend’s continuous support has helped me the most. They remind me that there is more to life than keeping my nose in a book. They are people I can vent to, and can vent to me. Being a part of PEERS my first two years at UCLA helped me create a foundation for my friend group, and showed me that it was okay to not have a 4.0 and not make it look like everything was perfect. It also helps that I live 2-3 hours away, so I can leave UCLA if I feel like I need to get away.
InhibitFactor: I feel like being gay has been a source of a lot of social pressure. While UCLA has many students, being in the community makes it feel small which can be a good and bad thing. I think that gay life at UCLA can be cliquey at times, and it makes me wonder if I am not a “good enough gay” sometimes, whatever that means.

HelpFactor: The huge diversity at UCLA
InhibitFactor: The anxiety mainly I get from exams

HelpFactor: I've been very fortunate to have found clubs that emphasize a sense of community here at UCLA. A lot of the events are socials or events that force you to talk a lot, which has helped me come out of my shell more and become more outgoing. This has helped me academically, socially, and emotionally, because I am constantly surrounded by people who always supports me no matter what.
InhibitFactor: My roommate last year would have sex with his girlfriend while I was in the room. This year I am obviously not rooming with him, and have found my living situation so much more comfortable and satisfying. I would say that really impacted me last year, but again, since I had such great friends, I was never that impacted academically or socially.

HelpFactor: Friends who share your same struggle and understand what you are going through because they are going through it too.
InhibitFactor: Feeling less compared to others constantly both academically and economically. Others seem to have it all while I do not and struggle sometimes with school. Being at the same academic level as everyone who came from a good high school or have educated parents (most people here) is hard and financial burdens are constantly at the back of my mind.

HelpFactor: AAP/programs in the CPO - their free student-led services (catered to communities of color) helped me get through my academics
InhibitFactor: Imposter syndrome/the stress of the quarter system/homesickness

HelpFactor: AAP/programs in the CPO - their free services (led by students of color) helped me succeed academically by providing me with personalized academic support
InhibitFactor: Imposter syndrome/the quarter system

HelpFactor: making friends and having a close group of individuals has made me feel more at home here.
InhibitFactor: feeling like I do not academically compare to other students in my major and feeling less smart around them

HelpFactor: Having people that cared about me and a small but solid support group as well as learning to reach out when I was struggling.
InhibitFactor: My mental health and self-esteem took a dive when I first came to UCLA.

HelpFactor: My friends have been great support to help me succeed at UCLA
InhibitFactor: I stress too much and overthink things a lot, which has made my experience at UCLA difficult at times

My friends from high school and college bot help me succeed academically, socially, emotionally at ucla. They are the ones I reach out to when things get difficult. It's nice to see my high school friends over the break.
InhibitFactor: The size of the school feels intimidating some times. Also, while in high school most of the students seemed to be open to helping one another, at UCLA, I feel a huge sense of competition.

HelpFactor:
meeting friends from diverse ethic backgrounds but who are all first generation college students.

Loved being able to find an internship that helped me meet like minded people that were also very friendly.

the events on campus that offer students the chance to explore the cuty

The way I see others mistreating the facilities management and food service workers made me feel like I didn't belong with people who mistreated others like that.

All these fires and the way the school dealt with thtem in the past has scared me and made me lose trust in UCLA a bit.

HelpFactor: Being apart of clubs outside of my major or field of study helps me. For example, I am in Bruin Film Society and frequently attend film screenings in LA to make sure I get out and it helps me make more friends.
InhibitFactor: The stress of feeling incompetent compared to my peers who are volunteering in hospitals, in pre-med clubs, etc has definitely put a strain on my emotional success as I feel at times that I do not do enough.

HelpFactor: being in residential life, being in clubs, being immersed in a community with the same passion
InhibitFactor: not having a significant other, becoming lonely in the dorms, being stressed

HelpFactor: Family, friends, etc.
InhibitFactor: N/A

HelpFactor: Surrounding myself with a good support system (my best friend since high school who has a very similar major as me and goes through much of the same things as me, my boyfriend who is always supporting me and cheering me up when I get anxious or depressed about an exam, my friends from musicals that allow me to forget about the STEM stuff and enjoy something as freeing as music every once in a while, one of my other best friends who is a North campus major who understands how much work a South campus major has but also reminds me to take a break and hang out with her every once in a while)
InhibitFactor: My own personal anxiety/depression when it comes to exams or grades. Often times when I do poorly on an exam or I feel like I did something wrong/something I regret, I keep dwelling on it. I will give myself a pep talk to get out of my funk but start thinking about it obsessively again an hour or two later.

HighGPA: NA
HelpFactor: friends and proactive professors

Being a high achiever and wanting to graduate with Latin Honors helped me stay on track, However, this often gives me anxiety when it comes to academics. If I don’t do as well I would have liked, I beat myself for it. I am very hard on myself, but this has helped me keep my GPA up. Emotionally, my boyfriend of almost 5 years has helped me through college. It helped being able to vent and release feelings of dissatisfaction and disappointment with myself. Socially, I still feel like I don’t belong. I don’t enjoy being out every night; I think it’s tiring. However, I enjoy talking on the phone with my love ones!
InhibitFactor: Not wanting to fit and not fitting in is not a good feeling. I won’t have anyone to take grad pictures with or people to go out with to escape from school. I like to save money and to rest after a long week of classes. Trying to get along with other people to me is exhausting but it would be nice to have someone I can relate to.

HelpFactor: The demographic at this school does not reflect that of the actual country, and that is a good thing. Being surrounded by other minorities helps foster this kind of utopic community where almost everyone has a group they can identify with, whether it be culturally or socially. These support systems have helped me succeed at UCLA.
InhibitFactor: This school is number 1 at the moment and that begins to foster a lot of competition between other students. This subconscious and unavoidable comparison to others can diminish one's confidence in their-self and therefore affect their success.

HelpFactor: Some factors that have helped me academically improve is studying in a group and being more confident in myself. I am still working on my emotional issues but something that does help is crying, calling my mom or sister, and talking to my roommates about my issues.
InhibitFactor: Factors that have prevented my success academically is the background I received in high school, which was not sufficient to what I need to succeed at UCLA. I have had to learn on my own how to perform well academically and how not to compare myself to others.

HelpFactor: Having roommates has helped me succeed socially at UCLA. I have learned how to live with people, which is an important skill to know. You learn how to interact.
InhibitFactor: Classes are tough. The quarter system is fast paced so you have to keep up or get left behind. It is just too fast in my opinion.

HelpFactor: finding clubs that I enjoy participating in and making friends with people that support my success and help me grow
InhibitFactor: poor study habits and an untreated learning disability

HelpFactor: friends, clubs

HelpFactor: I have experienced the worst anxiety of my life at UCLA. I have panic attacks regularly and sometimes cannot eat or sleep for many days at a time. I have not felt academically supported here. I have had bosses who have been biased against me. I have not had one thing handed to me at this school and yet I am one of the privileged people here. The only things that have helped me get through my academic, emotional, and social journeys here at UCLA have been my girlfriend, my job (gives me a schedule I must keep), and an occasional good nights rest.
InhibitFactor: I was an NSA on campus my sophomore year going into my junior year. I made many friends and was fairly popular among the students. I had a boss, however, who decided that she did not like me at the beginning of the summer. She bullied me in front of my coworkers. She was rude to me and completely destroyed any confidence I had in myself and my abilities of getting through college myself. Another thing that made it very hard for me to get through college was coming out as gay to my family and friends. My family does not acknowledge this lifestyle and my hometown shames it. I was so scared and nervous that it distracted me from my friends and school work. I began not doing anything at all. I wouldn't leave my room. I would hardly eat. I really needed some kind of support that I just didn't have. This affected my grades and social and emotional lives. This is something I still struggle with being comfortable with. Nothing has gone my way at this school. I am tired and frustrated with UCLA and I cannot wait to leave.

HelpFactor: my friends as my emotional support group; and resources like AAP
InhibitFactor: professors, classes/series that arent standardized; personal reasons

HelpFactor: Time has honestly been the biggest factor in my success here. The longer I have been here the better student I have become, my GPA has increased every year. I also joined a sorority and that has been a game changer for me socially.
InhibitFactor: The students are extremely competitive with each other, some of the faculty are clearly here just for research purposes and don't care about student learning. It can be hard to know where to look for help when I need something because the school is so big. A series of classes I was taking ended before I took the last class and even though I took the replacement upper division class, I still can't register for classes on my own because the enrollment system thinks I didn't finish the series.

HelpFactor: Support from friends, especially those who are experiencing the same things as I am (classes/social life). Extracurriculars are a good way to relax and spend less time stressing which in turn helps me succeed academically, socially, and emotionally.
InhibitFactor: Time management is an issue that has often inhibited my success emotionally and socially. I let my commitments to my academics inhibit my social life because I am stressed about getting good grades and such.

HelpFactor: My roommates supporting me when im down or stressed, as well as teachers ensuring me that my grade will be fine. Clubs helped me socially. Going out and being social with friends is essential fro your sanity.
InhibitFactor: Professors with a disorganized method of teaching and not caring for the students, only their own professionalism and success.

HelpFactor: everyone struggling together makes me feel like I am not the only one.
InhibitFactor: bad professors

HelpFactor: asd
InhibitFactor: ads

HelpFactor: I have enjoyed the social factors at UCLA that definitely help me the most. I have an amazing support system of friends and know that we all push and help each other. They also provide daily joy in my life. Academically the additional hours outside of lectures and discussion for many classes is what is most beneficial.
InhibitFactor: Some of the professors have been unhelpful, or do not match their tests with the lectures. Emotionally sometimes the stress and "imposter syndrome" get to hurt my belief in academic capabilities. Sometimes I also get homesick.

HelpFactor: CAPS, tutoring from friends because I can't get into AAP, clubs I identify with(and time to be able to connect with the people in these clubs)
InhibitFactor: Death of a loved one, the Pre-Meds(aggressive, highly competitive ones that will do literally anything for an A), the general switch from home life to college life

HelpFactor: Due to large class sizes and limited interactions with professors, I became more experienced in self teaching and gaining help from peers.
InhibitFactor: My relationship with family, friends, and my significant other caused emotional stress throughout my first year at UCLA. It was difficult managing my time between academics, work, and my social life and I often had to compromise my sleep and well being. I was taking two math classes over the summer when I was going through a breakup. I had to drop the classes because it was too much for me to bear. During this time i was also going through housing issues with my roommates and this made it impossible for me to focus on my studies.

HelpFactor: As a first gen student, my whole life I knew I wanted a college education and that I would get one, it was just up to me to figure out exactly how to achieve it. I think my own personal drive and pressure I put on myself to succeed has been one of the most important factors in this. Here at UCLA though, all of the extracurricular opportunities that have helped me discover my passions have also been helpful in helping me succeed socially and emotionally because even though lower divs for BS majors can be incredibly trying, all of the service work related to public health (what I want to do in the future)  I've been able to partake in really keep the end goal in mind and help me gain some perspective. Academically, I've been able to succeed with the help of my friends also going through the same struggles and with resources like AAP- peer learning has been a life saver.
InhibitFactor: Imposter syndrome is a 100% real concept and especially being from such a marginalized community (Native Hawaiian), I am constantly question whether or not I do in fact belong in spaces like this. In STEM classes especially this is incredibly challenging and I often still find myself comparing myself to other students here. I think that the way lower div science courses are taught here is also intimidating especially for students who came out of high schools without the same resources as others.

HelpFactor: Professor Lavelle set up soooo many office hours//undergraduate assistant hours. Generally, going to PLF sessions has helped me although I am not technically an AAP student. My all time favorite professor at UCLA, Dr. Tobolowsky, helped me succeed academically the most. He had the fairest tests that I've ever taken in my life and made it so that only content in his lecture slides was on the exam. Emotionally, I think my friends have helped me succeed the most. Their constant love and support has really kept me going.
InhibitFactor: This school has done absolutely nothing to benefit my mental health. I would honestly argue that it has steadily declined since coming here. If I didn't have the friends that I have, I think this school would've driven me so crazy by now that I would either have transferred or be dead.

HelpFactor: I think having friends from my hometown has helped.
InhibitFactor: I feel like, to some extent, students are hostile towards each other since it's a constant competition

HelpFactor: My prior education has been a huge part of my success at UCLA, I was privileged enough to attend a small high school that focused on college prep and college admissions. Socially, since the environment at UCLA is very collaborative, I've learned a lot from my peers than I expected I ever would and receive guidance and emotional/professional support from the campus communities I'm a part of.
InhibitFactor: I have had several health problems throughout my college years that have prevented me from performing as well as I could academics-wise, additionally I've dealt with mental health issues and trauma during my years at UCLA which have caused minor setbacks.

HelpFactor: I feel like good professors and TAs make a world of difference to my learning and overall happiness at school. When I'm happy in class, I'm happy outside of it. Most times I've been lucky and had caring professors and helpful TAs. Clubs have been a great way for me to destress and make friends that make each day at school better.
InhibitFactor: The size of all the STEM classes is pretty crazy. It's hard to get to know people because there's so much chaos and variance each class. It makes school feel like the opposite of home and that you're just a number. I know this is a widely known issue and it's not really UCLA's fault and one it can fix, but it's a big bummer.

HelpFactor: My frie nds
InhibitFactor: finding a job after college

HelpFactor: Having friends that were very open-minded and kind helped me cope a lot. Many professors are welcoming and tell us that we are free to talk to them about whatever even if it is not academically related.
InhibitFactor: Learning still feels competitive, counseling services aren't as readily available like it is advertised because it is very hard to make appointments, signing up for classes is difficult and stressful because of schedule conflicts with major classes and getting late enrollment times. Housing is very expensive & if it is affordable, it is cramped because I have to live with 4-5 other people.

HelpFactor: I made a great group of friends that grew up with more opportunities than I did. They help me and motivate me to keep going when times get rough. It is hard to always get the short end of the stick even though I feel like I work harder than they do.
InhibitFactor: I come from a small town and coming here it made me realize everything I missed out on to prepare myself for such a challenging school. It gets hard to see others succeed and be able to learn so efficiently and easily.

HelpFactor: The factors that have helped me succeed at UCLA is having a community and group of friends that I can turn to when I feel challenged.
Good teachers, that's it.
InhibitFactor: I commute from home, it's a two hour commute to go and another 2 to come back home. More if there is traffic. I feel like the hours sitting on the bus are wasted. I try to study on the bus or do some kind of work but it is difficult. I don't have a lot of friends either since I live off campus, it's difficult to forge bonds. I've also never been good at asking for help when I need it, convinced I can figure it out on my own. Personally, I think the education system is broken. I think tests are a good way to evaluate what one has learned, but not reviewing the examinations. Passing students who understood 70% of the material and then moving on to the next subject that requires an understanding of the material one only understood 70%, that logic is flawed. I also don't feel my high school prepared me for college, and while there are various resources put in place to help people like me I'm not able to participate in many of them.

HelpFactor: A supportive group of friends and family
InhibitFactor: Large class sizes and heavy competetition :/

HelpFactor: I joined a sorority sophomore year and this helped a lot with meeting more people which improved my social experience at UCLA and also helped me meet a lot of other people taking the same classes as me to help me out academically.
InhibitFactor: My sophomore year I messed around a lot my spring quarter and didnt spend as much time studying honestly because I was distracted by social events and a boy. not proud of it lol

HelpFactor: Professors like Will Conley, Mitra Hooshmand, Juan Herrera, Miguel-Angel Gutierrez, and Linda Zanontian come to mind when I think about fantastic professors dedicated to educating students and making them feel comfortable in the classroom.
InhibitFactor: UCLA has such a plethora of resources that it felt overwhelming for me to know where to start. As a second year now, I feel a lot of regret about not being involved on campus last year because I didn't know what to do.

HelpFactor:
Finding success and companionship within my field/major was much more difficult than I ever expected. When I started at UCLA, I felt an immense pressure like never before to prove to my peers that I’d earned my spot alongside them. As cynical as it may sound to say so, I found that talking to others in class often left me feeling drained and inferior. Pressure for success and perfection is applied as heavily by classmates as parents, professors, and institutions. It’s my third year and I’m only barely feeling as though I have my head above water, and this is only after I’ve made the decision to live off-campus. Distance is what helped me succeed at UCLA; I found that the distractions on campus— whether they took the form of chaotic roommates or unrelentingly perfect classmates— were too much for my mental health. Moving off-campus, into a quiet neighborhood with my partner, has proven invaluable to my ability to succeed academically at UCLA. However, I’ve undoubtedly had to sacrifice my social life as a result of this distance— I’m no longer close (spatially) to my friends, which makes it nearly impossible to ever see each other since we’re all so busy with the demands of school and extracurriculars. 

Ultimately, a bit of separation from campus culture is what I needed to succeed. Academia, especially STEM at UCLA, invites a toxic culture of achievement, comparison, and perfection, that is tangible to all students— but we ignore it, even choosing to participate if it’ll give us an advantage. I need as much distance from that as is reasonably possible.
InhibitFactor:
I failed my first Chem quiz at UCLA. It was the very first quiz I ever took in college, and I got a 50%. I’d never received a score so low on anything, and I was crushed, turning to my floormates and classmates to complain— and hopefully seek encouragement. I was met with almost satisfied suggestions to drop the course, to change majors, to change life paths. “This is going to be really, really difficult for you if you don’t even understand THAT.” “Are you sure you want to be pre-med?” “You know Chem’s only going to get harder.” Each person I spoke to smiled quietly at my (literal) failure, urging me to give up, convincing me that each test carried the weight of my entire future. I assumed I just had bad luck with floormates, so I started a group chat with a few classmates from my Chem class. One person texted and asked a basic conceptual question, to which another member replied “I can’t answer that. My parents read my messages and will be upset with me if they see I’m helping the competition.” 

At this point, only a few weeks into my freshman year, the toxic culture of UCLA pre-meds was entirely tangible— in fact, it had slapped me in the face. I was dejected. I felt like every person around me saw me as competition, rather than a classmate or peer that they could learn from (and vice versa). The environment that has been cultivated at UCLA, specifically in the STEM department, is absolutely crushing— and no one’s allowed to acknowledge that. If you acknowledge that this is hard, then you’ve lost. It often feels as though the expectation at UCLA is to be perfect, to never fail, to never blink an eye at the overwhelming expectations of classes and extracurriculars— because we’re Bruins, we’re the #1 public university. 

As someone with mental health issues, I’ve often found it detrimental to rise to the occasion. In order to do all that is expected of me, I have to sacrifice my social life, my personality, sleep, eating— school has to be my #1 priority at all times. Lack of routine, especially sleep and meal times, has destabilized my mental health every single quarter. I’m exhausted, and I can’t turn to my peers, because we’re all just supposed to pretend we’re doing fine. The intersection of the toxicity of campus culture and my own personal mental health issues often leaves me feeling at a disadvantage compared to other students (especially when you account for the lack of availability of sufficient psychological and psychiatric care from the University).

HelpFactor: I am a part of a club called Foundations Choreography. Through my club, I was able to expand my network, make friends, and make wonderful memories. Because of my club I had a place where I belonged at while studying at UCLA, which helped me survive UCLA.
InhibitFactor: None.

HelpFactor: joining an honor society and surrounding myself with successful people help motivate me
InhibitFactor: financial status

HelpFactor: I succeed academically because I am not involved in multiple clubs and I do not attend many social events. I devote most of my time to studying. Whenever I am on the bus, during that hour to hour and a half commute, I look over lecture notes or I catch up on some sleep. In terms of being emotionally successful, I believe I can handle the stress that comes with classes pretty well now. I remember being very anxious about my grades but now I just tell myself that there is no point in having self-doubt and ruminating over all the mistakes you have made. What's done is done and there is nothing to do but move on it. Learn from your mistakes and be happy about what is coming in the future and do not focus on what is in the past.
InhibitFactor: Not living on campus makes it very difficult to have a social life. I cannot live on or near campus because I cannot afford it. Because I don't live on campus, I don't really form long-term relationships with classmates since I only ever really see them in class. Moreover, since most social events and clubs have meetings in the evening or at night, it is difficult to attend them. I always have to be cognizant of when the last bus is and decide whether a social gathering is worth me walking home in the dark once I get off the bus. Moreover, at night, the bus has some strange people. One time, I stayed on campus for a club social until 10 pm. When I got on the bus to go back to my apartment, a man sat next to me and asked me questions on where I lived. He tried to lean his head on my shoulder and it made me very uncomfortable. This has made me not want to stay on campus late at night, meaning I won't be able to attend social gatherings and make friends.

HelpFactor: I have a great group of sorority sisters that have supported me here at UCLA.
InhibitFactor: My academics are really hard and its hard for my friends/sisters to relate because they are north campus majors. I have to rely on outside sources to help and sometimes I feel uncomfortable asking for help from those i do not know.

HelpFactor: Joining in clubs really helps me come over struggles in socially and emotionally.
InhibitFactor: Too much work and stress in my major.

HelpFactor: I've had many great professors who make classes interesting, mentors who have inspired me, and friends that support me.
InhibitFactor: Mental health has inhibited my success academically, socially, and emotionally. It's something I still struggle with everyday but I'm getting help and I want to believe I have a good support system.

HelpFactor: Family support and openness to listen and talk to me at all times, support of a few good friends, joining a dance team, academic struggles early in my second year of college have motivated me more
InhibitFactor: failed friendships/romantic relationships, feeling of being alone at UCLA, being an average student, stress induced by UCLA classes, a string of unhelpful professors and TAs, highly competitive UCLA atmosphere, large distance from home

HelpFactor: My friendships have definitely helped me in dealing with feeling alone or stress from academics. Being part of clubs that shift your mind to other activities has also helped. Overall having family and friends emphasize the need for mental health rather than consuming yourself in doing well 100% of the time.
InhibitFactor: Feeling as though I belong at UCLA because their is a lack of representation of people from my ethnic background has affected me. Being a first generation student and not knowing what college entailed fully has also been an obstacle. Also not being fully aware of the resources available as soon as I started freshman year has been a struggle.

HelpFactor: What has helped me succeed the most at UCLA is my boyfriend. I met him Fall Quarter freshman year at UCLA and he has helped me the most in school. He is always there for me and I feel like we are always in things together. It’s nice knowing we can do better academically and emotionally when we have each other. I truly couldn’t have gotten this far without him.
InhibitFactor: Being away from my family, having to work, and sometimes struggling with balancing a social life, and keeping up academically.

HelpFactor: Friends, Family
InhibitFactor: Family

HelpFactor: Family support, having a nice cultural/religious community on campus, having friends in my major, self-confidence
InhibitFactor: over-confidence, anxiety

HelpFactor: I found that when I first came to UCLA, I was very home sick. I found that calling my mom always help with my emotional, social or academic problems. At one point I called crying about not feeling like I was capable of handling my classes and she responded with "It's okay, this isn't high school anymore, this is adult school, it's suppose to be challenging." Other than that, I found that I made a hobby here. I like to go to muscle beach and do the traveling rings. I've meet so many new people there and it was a good way to keep my mind off of stress and for me to feel like I was in cheer again.
InhibitFactor: Week 2 of my freshman year, me and my boyfriend of two years broke up (I know its cliche, but I really took it hard), we both go here so I saw him continuously. That entire year was rough emotionally and socially. I could barely meet anyone, could never sleep, and was distracted from my studies. My sophomore year my fafsa lowered and I ended up gettin a job to compensate which took up a lot of my time. Overall, I'd say it took me a while to adjust but I very happy at UCLA, regardless of the struggles.

HelpFactor: Visiting my academic counselor at least once a quarter has helped me to ease my anxiety regarding academics.
InhibitFactor: Not being able to live at UCLA has inhibited me from making more friends and or forming study groups.

HelpFactor: Joining student organizations really helped with my transition into UCLA. Upon joining the Campus Tours organization at UCLA, I was welcomed into a family consisting of such diverse people that have truly shaped my college experience. I am constantly learning from them, and laughing with them - they allowed me to experience what it's like to have friends turn into family.
InhibitFactor: The times of my college career in which I wasn't branching out as much socially have been the most challenging for me in every regard. Being socially isolated heightened any school-related anxiety I was facing and ultimately left me feeling like I didn't belong at UCLA.

HelpFactor: I honestly think that joining organizations that I am passionate about has helped me the most in feeling like I have succeeded at UCLA. Being able to share my talents and resources to others gives me a lot of motivation.
InhibitFactor: Just feeling like I am a number amongst everyone else. It is so easy to feel insignificant in such a huge school. I feel inhibited when I feel like professors do not remember me.

HelpFactor: The one thing keeping me going is the thought of the expectations my parents have put on me, and the support form my closest circle of friends.
InhibitFactor: I have struggled with having confidence in myself, I have felt like I don't belong here, that I am not as smart as everyone else, and this has led me to isolate myself and lag on my academics. Also, I think that to succeed at UCLA you need to be social and outspoken in order to get your needs solved. This is something I struggle with a lot because I don't have the ability to just start talking to someone and asking questions.

GPA: NA
HighGPA: NA

HelpFactor: My faith
InhibitFactor: my own stress and anxiety

HelpFactor: Having a social support group at UCLA has been a great pillar for my success throughout college as it provides a group to lean on and socialize with, struggle with in academics, and turn to in times of need. Specifically, when I found out my father was diagnosed with cancer, my roommates and close friend group were the first people I turned to for a shoulder to lean on and speak comfortably about my emotions such that I could cope with circumstance in a healthy manner.
InhibitFactor: Large class sizes inhibit my success at UCLA by preventing more personalized relationships with professors and resources allocated to students individually.

HelpFactor: definitely friends I've made here because they're so supportive, professors that give many many resources for us to succeed (Professor Lavelle provides so much resources for Chem and I love it because I suck at Chem)
InhibitFactor: workload from classes and extracurricular commitments, also the many many rejections I've gotten from organizations

HelpFactor: Ethnic empowerment orgs
InhibitFactor: Feeling alone, home and personal problems, feeling minoritized at the school

HelpFactor: I go to office hours almost all the time. I also form study groups and try to understand concepts instead of just memorizing information.
InhibitFactor: Make sure you have a few VERY close friends you can lean back on. You'll need a strong support system if you want to survive here.

GPA: NA

HelpFactor:
-being in community with my fellowship! I've made a majority of my friends through this club.
-my high school. I feel like my high school did a really good job preparing me for the rigor and workload at UCLA.
-supportive family. My family is always glad to hear from me when I call home and I enjoy my conversations with them.
-supportive mentors. They're not official mentors, but older people throughout my time here at UCLA have helped me through difficult emotional and social moments in my life. They've also really encouraged me to try things I would have never been brave enough to try. I've had a lot of cool experiences because of some of these people. 
-interesting classes. I've really enjoyed some of my classes because I've opportunities to explore some of my very niche interests. 
-cultural nights. They've really inspired me to embrace my Asian American identity more. I'm more interested in learning about what it means to be Asian-American and fully appreciate my culture.
InhibitFactor:
-my stress/anxiety when it comes to exams and academics. I feel like I don't have a healthy coping mechanism and that I'm worrying and abnormal amount. I've been told that I stress so much that I start to stress other people around me (who don't usually get stressed). 
-lack of emotional understanding. I don't think I understand my emotions very well and how to process them. Therefore, I think I can run myself into the ground sometimes without noticing. Or I feel like my exhaustion and stress are normal. 
-imposter syndrome. Everyone here seems to be doing a lot. UCLA definitely feels very competitive. 
-dissatisfaction with myself. I have trouble feeling content with myself in every aspect. I have trouble recognizing my achievements. I struggle with body image. I feel like I can't compete with others. I'm always comparing myself to others.
-don't understand my mental health. I've never seen a therapist, though I feel like it might help. I don't know how mentally healthy I am. 
-procrastination

HelpFactor: studying, work, joining many orgs
InhibitFactor: non academic commitments

HelpFactor: My parents always give me perspective when i am having a hard time at UCLA
InhibitFactor: Myself and the people around me can inhibit me in some ways.

HelpFactor: My 4 friends are all smarter than me, so they help me in my classes. Emotionally they keep me company when I get icecream after a bad midterm. Socially, they are the people I get icecream with and keep me out of my apartment.
InhibitFactor: I am kind of slow, so I am unable to learn things as quickly. I also don't make friends that easily so it has inhibited my success in other fields besides academics.

HelpFactor: My boyfriend has been a big part of my support system and someone I always lean on. I am also an independent person which only strengthened when I moved away from home.
InhibitFactor: My parents are sometimes not understanding of how difficult UCLA really is which adds unnecessary stress to my already hectic workload. Working has also taken a lot of time out of my day, and figuring out what I want to do with my life has also added a lot of stress.

HelpFactor: Making friends in classes and having a support group has been very helpful.
InhibitFactor: I think the quarter system makes it hard to succeed at ucla especially for stem majors taking multiple classes with two rounds of midterms. The amount of midterms we have to take in such a short span of time makes it hard to succeed academically while making time for other aspects of our lives.

HelpFactor: the friends I've made here are so supportive and I love hanging out with them, professors that provide lots of resources for us to succeed in the class (Professor Lavelle is the best in providing lots of resources for Chem especially for students like me who aren't good at Chem)
InhibitFactor: workload of classes and extracurricular commitments clashing with each other, the amount of rejections I've received for extracurricular organizations/clubs :(

HelpFactor: support network
InhibitFactor: friendship fallouts, drinking/partying/smoking too much and overall drama, roommate conflicts/menial/unnecessary conflicts due to the whole roommate situation which gave me a LOT of anxiety during my last two years here at UCLA.

HelpFactor: Perseverance
InhibitFactor: Worrying all the time

HelpFactor: It's hard to be specific but one thing that helped a lot was my connections. Not to UCLA directly but to people in the scientific world who helped get me interested in and experience with stem very early on. In addition, I grew up with enough wealth to be able to afford college which has helped me greatly.
InhibitFactor: I'm quite extroverted which is a hard trait to live with as someone with high functioning autism. I struggle to relate to other people but I live for human interactions. Navigating this was a massive struggle throughout middle and high school and I've only recently in my life managed to "solve" it.

HelpFactor: I did the AAP Freshmen Summer Program which helped me meet a bunch of new people as soon as I got to UCLA so I didn't feel as overwhelmed when starting Fall quarter of my freshmen year. This helped because the AAP community is very supportive and provides a lot of resources for the students.
InhibitFactor: I came from a city that did not have that many resources for students who were interested in pursuing a career in stem. My high school didn't even offer chemistry which was a major setback being pre-med and coming into a school as prestigious as UCLA.

HelpFactor: Having several groups of friends separate from each other has been helpful to reducing social anxiety - therefore, participation in multiple different clubs has been helpful for me
InhibitFactor: I sometimes get the impression that since UCLA has so many students, the process of "getting involved" takes a lot more effort than it seems. It often feels like there's a lengthy application to so many clubs and majors that I think the application progress has deterred me from pursuing more things in the past.

HelpFactor: My roommates freshman year really made the transition to UCLA extremely smooth and I am still such good friends with them. They really made the transition so easy and I got so lucky meeting them.
InhibitFactor: N/A

HelpFactor: being a part of clubs and having a tightly knit group of friend
InhibitFactor: overwhelming work and school load

HelpFactor: The most helpful factor at UCLA has been my sorority Phi Lambda Rho because there are many sisters from a variety of majors and we are all women of color and understand the challenges that we face. It is extremely empowering and helpful to know that I have a support system here at UCLA.
InhibitFactor: The fact that there are not many people of color here has been challenging because I feel excluded and other people often take up the space. also it is extremely competitive and classes are often regarded as "weed out" classes which Is disheartening to hear because we should be in classes to prepare us for our intended careers instead of making us feel like if we do bad in a class it is over for us and we should look into something else. "Weed out" classes are intended for low income people of color to not succeed which is why you see the demographics of STEM majors and careers unequal are more towards white people.

HelpFactor: Making friends with people in my major or similar major allowed for study groups, friendships, and even close relationships with a few people that allowed me to gain an insight into what I should do with my life and how I can get there.
InhibitFactor: My anxiety and fear of failure has held me back a lot and prevented me from taking all the opportunities I can to further my academic and social standing. It's a work in progress but I wish that it wasn't such a prevalent problem in my life.

HelpFactor: Talking to older students in my major to help guide me through the major.
InhibitFactor: Overcommitting during my first year

HelpFactor: great support system and friends, studying a little everyday

HelpFactor: AAP peer learning and counseling, talking to mom, talking and making friends with people in classes
InhibitFactor: A lot of students and hard to get classes you need like stats 13. Also, I don't get financial aid or government aid so i have to work to go here. This year i am taking a break to focus on academics, but i should be working.

HelpFactor: The majority of it has been creating a support network with my friends and community, AAP
InhibitFactor: Impostor syndrome, having no background in research, coming in with less knowledge than some of my better off peers, MCDB is extremely inaccessible for offering support on classes and offering classes that have space and good quality professors, MCDB labs in specific require an unrealistic time commitment (10+ hours/week) making it hard for working students with no research experience, no holistic support for students only academic

My professors in my more specialized classes are incredible, and inspire me to want to learn.

HelpFactor: My parents dealing with all my financial needs has been the number one contributing factor to my success at UCLA. Not having to worry about anything other than school has made my school experience much easier than I imagine many other people's experiences have been.

Ethnic: I would prefer not to say
HelpFactor: Having friends from similar majors helps a lot because you can work together and answer each other's questions since we all go through similar experiences in our stem classes.
InhibitFactor: Having better access to opportunities would help, since I think with so many out there it makes it harder to find what works for you.

HelpFactor: AAP has helped me succeed at UCLA with their community building, workshops, and peer learning.
InhibitFactor: I do not feel as comfortable seeking help from my professors and TA's because I learn better with one on one time and I get a bit nervous in groups

HelpFactor: I'm part of an athletic team and having a team of people who understand what its like to be a D1 athlete while also maintaining good grades and staying focused on academics help motivate me to be successful
InhibitFactor: being busy all the time. Im one of the few stem majors on my team, and having to have a full practice schedule while also having a heavy class schedule with hard classes can really take a toll on me emotionally AND physically. Since I need to wake up at 5:30 AM every morning for practice, my whole day I'm trying to get ahead, doing work and running around from place to place so I can make sure Im in bed around 9:30 pm. Realistically, I have a fraction of the time to do work and study than most non athletic students, as I spend most days doing my sport for 4 hours and have to go to bed early, spend time recovering in the training room, etc.

HelpFactor: Getting enough sleep, exercising regularly, and eating healthy have helped me succeed in all ways. I did all three of these things one quarter, and I got straight A's. I have not been able to do this again, but I am hopeful. Additionally, making sure one's study list is not dominated by hard classes is helpful. I didn't feel emotionally comfortable at UCLA until I established my support group, including friends and family from home and my friends here. I find it much easier to study outside of my dorm room. Lastly, clubs and retreats for my major have helped me to make friends within my major. I think I got lucky making friends outside of my major.
InhibitFactor: Not sleeping, not eating healthy, and not exercising have hindered my success. In addition, my social media addiction makes it harder to get assignments done on time, and I am very easily distracted, especially if I am working in my room. The biggest thing that hindered my success at UCLA was Imposter Syndrome. I was afraid to ask for help academically because I was afraid people would "find out" that I was wrongfully accepted to UCLA. Now I know that I earned my place here.
