InhibitFactor: Lapses in the above factors

HelpFactor: PLFS!! joining clubs/orgs. Self-care days have helped a lot.
InhibitFactor: too much on my plate. felt like I had no support.

HelpFactor: Learning time management was a major lesson that I learned to help me succeed.

My family supporting me has helped me at UCLA academically and emotionally. I am out of state and my family lives on the east coast. They are much more concerned that my learning and well being are in order than my GPA being perfect which has helped me not stress as much. I also have really appreciated getting support from CAE and getting medication from my doctor which has helped my emotional well being.
InhibitFactor: The pre-med culture at UCLA has inhibited me in my emotional well being and in my studies. I am not pre med but it feels like everyone else in my major is and there is an expectation for all pre meds to have perfect grades which leads to everyone asking me about my grades and stressing me out by how stressed out they are and I feel like everyone in my major is trying to compete with me which makes me feel inadequate.

HelpFactor: Joining a club and becoming really involved in it
InhibitFactor: Just a lot of school work stress

HelpFactor: I went to a high school that dual enrolled us in community college classes. Our campus was a set of trailers on their campus. Everything was public, this was a very typical underfunded school in LAUSD. I took a full load of high school courses and AP classes along with being half-time in community college from the age of 14. I graduated with two AA degrees. This taught me how to deal with less sleep, a heavy workload, and how to advocate for myself.
InhibitFactor:
I struggle with severe migraines and other health issues, but because I look fine to most people, they don't understand the kind of pain I'm in. I don't mention it to instructors any more because they think I'm exaggerating. I can't control them. Also, it's more than just a headache. They are a full neurological attack. Last quarter, I got them 6-8 times a month. Now i'm working with a team of doctors to try and lower the frequency and intensity. 
I'm also a working student, and that cuts into my time. I also don't drink or use drugs. Both of my parents and most of my family struggle with addiction, so I'm extremely careful to not touch any of it. It's hard to be regularly social on weekends without drinking. I'm very happy with my decision, but other people my age often don't understand it.

HelpFactor: I am a very independent person so my independence helps me handle all the struggles of college life. I do not use many resources for assistance at UCLA. Friends help a lot of the time and that is about it.
InhibitFactor: None that I can think of.

HelpFactor: The major factors that have impacted my academic success at UCLA are the professors and the resources that they offer. Almost all of the professors that I've encountered have been such nice people, and willing to offer assistance at any point. I think that a combination of CAPS and meeting peers who are in the same types of situations contributed most to my social and emotional success while here.
InhibitFactor: I don't think that there have been any factors that have inhibited my academic success. However, I think that the lack of diversity, especially in South Campus has really inhibited my social and emotional growth at UCLA.

HelpFactor: For me, CAPS has been essential for social and emotional stability. Academically, the freedom to control my time and priorities has made school much nicer than it was in high school.
InhibitFactor: I feel stunted by busy work. I came to UCLA to pursue a career in research and since I have been working in a lab I've done a lot of work on my own independent project. I think that for some courses, the work that is recommended is reasonable, but for other courses, I feel that a grasp of the material was achieved without the need for the assignments that are given to us. I believe that as an adult I should choose how best to develop an understanding of the concepts shown to me, and that my test scores will reflect my judgement. I should be able to spend more time in a lab where time is spent bettering other people rather than filling out meaningless papers with already established facts or formulas.

HelpFactor: I found a good and supportive group of friends that help me grow as an individual.
InhibitFactor: The class competitiveness especially if it is curved

For socially, just be open and be willing to meet people from different ethnicity and cultural background. For my emotions, I would either listen to music or write down thoughts. Talking to a friend or a counselor would definitely help as well.
InhibitFactor: Procrastinating and waiting till the end. I tend to have a habit of socializing first before doing my academic work.

HelpFactor: Being on good terms with roommates and classmates definitely help. I think generally most people are really easy to get along with and my roommates and people I've met at office hours and in clubs have become some of my closest friends here. As UCLA students overall, we have a lot of common ground.
InhibitFactor: External factors are really hard to control. Recently things happening at home have made focusing on academics and life at UCLA a little hard. In addition, it's sometimes hard to feel engaged in large lecture halls, especially in many of the science pre-reqs here. I studied abroad over the summer and I loved feeling like an actual student in a classroom again rather than just a number. We had really small classes (15 students max) and they were discussion based. People were actually interested in sharing their perspectives and thoughts and I loved being in a more dynamic environment. Meanwhile, I feel like the large lecture styles here discourage engagement just because it's easier to get distracted and such. Discussion sections help but I feel most people are still as disengaged as in lecture. :(

HelpFactor: having a strong base of support has helped me immensely. whenever I experience large amounts of stress, what reassures me is that my family says they value my mental health over anything else, so that as long as I try my best that's all that matters, and everything else will fall into place when the time is right.
InhibitFactor: I've had multiple surgeries while at UCLA, as well as personal issue that are were hard to ignore

HelpFactor: finding a great community in my Christian club, having friends that support me, prioritizing academics but leaving room for fun
InhibitFactor: hyper competitive atmosphere

HelpFactor: the academic support from PEERS supplemental workshops, which made me learn in collaboration with my peers, which i would not have done on my own; AAP peer learning which helped me stay on track with material and not get behind; my job with BruinCorps helped me stick with my values and it provided me with peers who were supportive; CCM surrounded me with peers with similar desire to serve underserved communities
InhibitFactor: setup of discussions, where it was hard to participate because I wasn't as fast to formulate my thoughts as my peers; not feeling comfortable enough to go to office hours because I didn't feel like I could relate to professor

HelpFactor: Advice from mentors. Starting a job at the undergraduate writing center. joining clubs like the ski and snowboard team.
InhibitFactor: lack of access to good college and future counseling. My advisors are hard to get appointments with and aren't that knowledgable about things I care about. Also I really really wish I had more opportunities to interact meaningfully with professors.

HelpFactor: For me, it was joining clubs that helped me build a community. Because UCLA is so large, finding a way to make the school feel a bit smaller. I don't think I would be able to thrive if it weren't for a small community.
InhibitFactor: I don't think it's easy to find ways to find more professional help for  things. A lot of my support is based on advice from friends, not actual adult counselors.

HelpFactor: Factors that have helped me succeed thus far include: PEERS, AAP,  PLFs, and my family. Academically plfs have aided me significantly; I saw my exams grades increase after I began enrolling in sessions.
InhibitFactor: First of all, my background in certain subjects has affected my success. Coming from a low socioeconomic background I did not receive the same education as other students. This was very evident when I began any series courses. Additionally, my mom's health has been getting worse and the guilt of being away from her truly affects my progress.

HelpFactor: friends being supportive and meeting people that believe in you in an environment where you're not typically praised at all unless you do something significantly well... amazing support academic programs such as aap, peers, and more. :) essentially, people and organizations that make one feel human again. with so many students, it's hard to not feel like a number. finding communities of people like you roots you and reminds you who you are, while diverse communities allow you to see the beautiful complexity of the world and know that even though we're different, we all have similar fears and thats comforting.
InhibitFactor: so many students, not having enough time for office hours because of many students or not being able to ask a quick question after lecture because my next class is so far!

HelpFactor: Being open and available to strike conversations and talk to anyone I come across during my day.
InhibitFactor: First experiences of love and heartbreak and lacking the pathways to make sense of newfound emotions, CAPS being relatively underwhelming and ineffectual. There is a positive culture of opening up and showing your emotions, but little to no guidance about how to actually handle and function with strong feelings that are often unprecedented. Counseling/advice should help identify toxic behaviors and ways to avoid them rather than only allowing venting. Resources and opportunities are plentiful at UCLA but it's often hard to find them or build the courage/momentum to step decisively out of your comfort zone.

HelpFactor: CAPS, my family and my support system, Wazo connect peer support when I didn't have UCShip, meeting some solid friends my 3rd year.

HelpFactor: My friends have really helped me to feel successful here.

Being able to do fun activities in various clubs is a great way to de-stress.

HelpFactor: Hard work all the time. Emotional detachment is often necessary to get stuff done--just accepting the fact that you don't have time to take care of yourself and your social life is important early on.
InhibitFactor:
Sometimes I have to work until tears to get my work done at this school, because for a lot of assignments slacking off/failure is not an option and a low GPA isn't an option either. I feel like I'm always working and too drained/busy to do many social things--even exercise, and even on the weekends. 

Socially, I feel like it's extremely hard to make lasting connections here, especially as an introvert. Lower-division pre-med classes are structured in a way that you don't see people very often (or ever again) after you meet them, and the residential life programs are honestly lacking in activities that help people make lasting friendships either. That leaves clubs (or greek life) as one of the only purely social outlets, but time is so finite when considering coursework that participating in these things to the fullest extent (or even at all) is extremely challenging and leaves you feeling guilty about the work that you neglected by participating in an extracurricular event.

HelpFactor: I would say the that having a strong support system and a good group of friends to be there to help you when you face academic hurdles. In my freshman year I struggled with failing my first class and I wouldn't have been able to continue going to UCLA without having them around me.
InhibitFactor: UCLA is already an academically challenging place to be but the rigor of class is emotionally draining and it can become overwhelming sometimes.

HelpFactor: Very social dorm floor during freshman year, strong work ethic, curiosity/enjoying a challenge, good dining and exercise facilities
InhibitFactor: Anxiety/insecurity, illness, dissatisfaction with some TA's and instructors

At UCLA, academically, while I did well my first quarter just based off of knowledge from high school, the following quarter I did not do well by my standards. This was from a lack of discipline and overwhelmingly bad habits that didn't help me do well academically. From then on, I have been more disciplined in setting aside time to study and also studying with people I deem to be very academically oriented as well. Socially, joining a social fraternity helped me find my family helped me feel adjusted at school. Of course, even if I didn't do the fraternity,  I would have found another friend/family group through other various campus organizations, but this was the route I chose. Emotionally, sometimes I feel drained, but it ultimately also feels tied to my physical state and when I'm not treating myself right, I don't feel as good.
InhibitFactor: Inhibition of my success sometimes came from who I chose to spend my time with. No one I have met has really been a malevolent factor in my academics but it's more like people who have different majors or a different workload had misguided me in the past where I felt like I didn't have to do work when I was with them because they didn't have work to do, but I totally did have work to do.

HelpFactor: College is an immensely stressful time. I feel as though the difficulty of social, academic, and emotional aspects of college can oftentimes compound upon each other. I have found that for the benefit of my emotional and social wellbeing, I sometimes have to relinquish control in my academic life to some extent. As a person who struggles with anxiety, it is healthier for me personally to accept that I'm not a perfect student and that all I can do is my best (corny, I know). Last year, I was the picture perfect pre-med. I was succeeding in difficult neuroscience upper division classes, working in two labs, doing a paid internship, and leading several student organizations. Although academically I was succeeding remarkably, I suffered in all other aspects of my life. I was constantly stressed, oftentimes to the point of being sick, I never slept, and I was miserable. It essentially destroyed me. Since then, I've taken a step back from academics and in doing so have a better handle on my emotional and social health.
InhibitFactor: I think the pressure to succeed and achieve constantly made me feel like if I wan't busy with school or extra-curriculars, I was failing at college. Similarly, I was bombarded with conflicting expectations of what my college experience should look like. On one hand, I was instructed to study hard, get good grades, pull all nighters if I had to, get involved, and develop marketable skills. On the other hand, I was told to have fun, enjoy my time, make friends that would last me a lifetime, and party hard. No matter what I felt like I was failing because being a successful college student is so romanticized, the definition so confounded, that it doesn't seem possible. You either aren't studying hard enough or partying hard enough unless you never sleep.

HelpFactor: My friends have helped me academically, as we all have similar majors and study together for our exams. Clickers are also helpful, as they engage students and personally keep me focused. My RA during my second year was very helpful in terms of emotional success as he was very supportive of me and my needs.
InhibitFactor: The large size of specific classes have made it difficult to ask questions or engage with my peers during lecture.

HelpFactor:
1. friends
2. clubs
InhibitFactor:
1. lack of diversity
2. culture shock

HelpFactor: Good support system (friends + family), hobbies, CAPS
InhibitFactor: Mental health (anxiety + depression), pressure to succeed academically but also socially

HelpFactor: Mostly the ability to socialize and understand those of different ethnic backgrounds as a product of a diverse upbringing. Additionally, my ability to cope with stress and work efficiently due to a competitive high school.
InhibitFactor: Things that inhibit success are large class sizes and faculty that are difficult to relate to.

HelpFactor: A stable home life, pressure for high academic achievement, parent involvement in school, and a strong circle of close, decent friends in the years leading to college.
InhibitFactor: Pressure high academic achievement, anxiety, and chronic depression.

HelpFactor: The factors that have helped me succeed academically is understanding how hard my parents worked for me to get here and how this is my one shot and to not fuck it up.
InhibitFactor: Coming into classes in which people already understand the material is a bit of a disadvantage but what can you do except work twice as hard.

HelpFactor: In general finding individuals who feel and think the same way. Finding people whom can relate to academic struggles. Socially, finding people who like to engage in the same activities outside of academics (partying, nightlife, etc).
InhibitFactor: Not feeling like I belonged at UCLA especially because of socioeconomic status and race. Felt out of place in classrooms and in the STEM setting because of the lack of diversity leading to a lot of self doubt and discouragement to engage with professors in office hours.

HelpFactor: Having a great support group helped.
InhibitFactor: Large class sizes and too many activities.

HelpFactor: Having supportive friends and roomates who have positively influenced my habits. My first 2 years I was really worried about my grades and would often pull all nighters. This changed when I moved into apartments with my close friends who really helped me realize that my behavior was not constructive. Since then, I have stopped stressing over grades. For example when I was taking my upper division classes last year, I very rarely stressed out about exams or assignments because I was so passionate about the course material and I would focus my attention to actually learn the course material to fufil my academic intrests. Forgetting about the grades and focusing on the learning has helped me tremendously so much. My grades improved significantly. For example, my 2nd year I earned a 3.68 GPA and during my junior year I not only finished all the upper division requirements for the MIMG major but I also earned a 4.0. I really think there needs to be a push for learning rather than grades in the lower division stem classes. Looking back, I could have appreciated the courses I took my first 2 years more if I had been studying for the purpose of learning/retaining the information rather than studying to get above the curve on exams.
InhibitFactor: I would often get sick while living in the dorms and this made it difficult to study for exams and complete assignments efficiently

HelpFactor: Having a job has given me many valuable skills that I can use in the future. Living in the dorms has given me friends for life who have made my experience so fun and positive.
InhibitFactor: Some of the classes teach too much material way too fast, which can make it hard or frustrating. Having 3 midterms in the span of two days this quarter, for example, made it feel impossible to perform at my best when all it did was make me exhausted mentally and physically.

HelpFactor: some of the factors include having found my group of friends who I can study with and who are my emotional support as well as having made close relationships with my coworkers who also serve as my emotional support especially as students at UCLA.
InhibitFactor: Having to work while also being a full time student has interfered with my studying schedule and success at UCLA mainly because I sometimes do not have the time for extra studying for my exams and I end up more exhausted than usual. I also have work while office hours are occurring as well as while study sessions and PLF sessions are occurring which do not allow me to be able to get the extra help I need.

HelpFactor: Joining the organization Hermanos Unidos helped me from dropping out.

HelpFactor: Factors that have helped me are being a part of a organization in order to find people that have similar interests and ideals as me, interacting with faculty when I need help, and being emotionally close with my family. It is always easier when you know there are people you can reach out to for anything, whether that is academically or personally. Additionally, having a mentor has helped me immensely when it comes to succeeding in terms of my future career.
InhibitFactor: Factors that have inhibited my success are the competitiveness of STEM majors, and the overall social pressures that are thrown onto young adults.

HelpFactor: I have made good friends by living with them. I feel because I saw them everyday, it made it easier for us to get close. I also joined a sorority with my close friends which I think helped me socially.
InhibitFactor: I feel UCLA is a really big school which is why it is actually harder to make friends. A lot of people know other people so it is hard to get close to someone. It is hard to put yourself out there and it can be very intimidating at first.

HelpFactor: My closest friends have helped me to get through my anxiety about grades as well as my social anxiety and depression. They usually take me off of campus to help me relax and increase my mindfulness. I also see a psychologist (near but not on campus) to assist and educate me on my mental health.
InhibitFactor: I have severe panic attacks and sometimes my anxiety prevents me from going to class and joining social clubs. During a pre-audition for a dance team, I had a panic attack due to the overwhelming amount of people that attended. I felt isolated and, most of all, mortified. I could not speak to anyone present there after it occurred.

HelpFactor: Finding a good supportive community of friends has helped me succeed at UCLA. Before I found my support system, I was doing very poorly even though I had a lot of time on my hands. Being around supportive people really helped me get more comfortable and gave me the tools I needed to perform at my best.
InhibitFactor: Heartbreak has caused me to perform poorly in school on multiple occasions.

HelpFactor: I tend to seek help when I need it, especially emotional support from my loved ones.
InhibitFactor: I do not feel comfortable going to office hours because I feel like a lot of the smarter kids are there to ask questions beyond the material we've learned and I feel like my questions will not be answered and I will end up leaving even more confused and less confident than when I walked in .

HelpFactor: Cultural-based student organizations and clubs on campus, AAP, CAPS, CAE.
InhibitFactor: Lack of adequate racial, ethnic, and socioeconomic diversity in the student body and in the faculty for STEM. Lack of understanding for people from marginalized groups and classes. Excluded, belittled, and disparaged by my white peers several times during my first year, which is why I have not sought their friendship in the years since then. During my second year when I was in a lab group with two white students and one other Latino student, the white students would hoard the lab materials and do the labs on their own, and would not let us use the equipment until they were done with the problems they were working on. They also refused to share the lab's findings with us, so my Latino lab mate and I would have to wait until the second half of class to rush through the lab on our own and turn in our results. As for the very few times (I think just once?) that they did let us see their results, they just held the lab in front of our faces and counted down from 10 before turning in the lab and declaring "and it's gone!", knowing we weren't able to copy everything down.

HelpFactor: Communication skills
InhibitFactor: Lack of sleep

FirstGen: Throughout my academic career, I was always struggling with procrastination. During a few of my quarters here when my classes were easier in terms of topics and work load, I was a little better with procrastinating and I finished assignments and studying ahead of time. When my classes were more difficult, my procrastinating habits got out of control.
STEM: I never had too much of a problem with emotional, social, or cultural issues. At times in my statistics and math classes, I felt like the minority since it felt that nearly everyone was Asian and they all had their cliques. Additionally, it felt that some of my classmates were so much smarter than I was, and that it was hopeless to even try to get on their level.
GPA: I joined the campus tour guides program my second year and that greatly improved my experience here at UCLA. I was able to meet so many nice and welcoming people who organized a lot of events together.
HighGPA: I know a lot of people who deal with procrastinating as a problem, I know that UCLA's CAPS (Counseling and Psychological Services) holds a number events that deal with handling procrastination, so perhaps make those more accessible to students. Mental health in general could be holding many STEM majors back due to the high intensity and stress, so more counseling and psychological help would go a long way perhaps.

FirstGen: Knowledge is sometimes abstract and it’s hard to understand
GPA: I think the campus has too many people and I don’t think the school or related college staff really cares about us. Way worse than the feeling in community college.
HighGPA: I have spent a year in UCLA and has one more year to go. I’m an applied math student and all math classes I’ve taken were with newly graduates as our instructors. I’m not discriminating those instructors but really the content taught in class and homeworks/exams were sometimes nonsense. I think for the teaching part UCLA should have a good system to have experienced senior professors train new instructors and pass the extraordinary quality to pass generations by generations. This can make UCLA’s teaching and learning process more consistent and efficient.

HighGPA: More tutoring sessions and more homework assignments to help us practice more.

GPA: I was able to immediately make friends here, with people from all different majors and backgrounds. I have always felt like I belonged here at UCLA
HighGPA: I do believe the workload is intense but I think that comes with the price of being on the quarter system. However I think moving to the semester system wont help that really.

Major: Applied Mathematics; Linguistics and Computer Science
FirstGen: All STEM major classes have massive weekly homework assignments, quizzes and tests. I feel like STEM major students have to go through more stressful situations than other students.
STEM: As a girl in STEM majors, there are a lot of situations where I take classes with a lot of boys and find it slightly hard to communicate. I've encountered teachers and students who judge girls differently as well. Moreover, sometimes language barrier makes it hard for me to discuss academic terms with others but I'm learning and trying.
GPA: Studying together with STEM major friends in my extracurricular club makes me realize that STEM people are everywhere and we are going through the challenges in college together.
HighGPA: I honestly do not think challenges should be minimized. Growing pains are necessary for everyone and if we do not face challenges in college, we are never going to learn anything important and cannot be well prepared for career life.

FirstGen: "Downcurving" grades, which is a popular practice in STEM subjects, made the environment feel competitive and unfriendly.
STEM: Very few times I've had outwardly egotistic/pompous TAs and classmates that made me feel small and not cut out for STEM.
GPA: Joining clubs/organizations and meeting people in them made me feel more part of the community. Also doing group work/projects in classes had the same effect for me.
HighGPA: I think the main challenge of STEM majors is the stress associated with classes. I believe that if there were more transparency/communication between students and the instructing staff, particularly about things like teaching methodology or making clear the intent of assigned work, then classes would be more humanized and feel less daunting to students.

FirstGen: When money is a problem to you and you want to finish off everything (your requirement for your major/minor) which forces you to take 4 classes every quarter.
STEM: When you have to live up the expectations of your big family as an Asian and at the same time have some poor financial background that kind of force you to find a part time job in order to pay your own rent etc.
GPA: Lack of sense of belonging when taking STEM classes everyone feels so individual compared when taking other general education class where everybody is so talkative to each other and take initiatives more.
HighGPA: Have a standard procedure to teach students in an organized way where every instructor is given the opportunity to learn how to keep on track and to keep students understand the class concepts step by step.

FirstGen: Feeling pressured to compete against other STEM students. Professors teaching in ways that didn't align with my learning style also made it difficult. Additionally, being in a class with a professor that doesn't give out all A's, compared to all the other professors who give out all A's.
STEM: Feeling pressured as a UCLA student, because of desire to succeed amongst such a smart population.
GPA: Joining different clubs made me feel very welcomed to UCLA. For example, I was able to meet so many good friends through Bruin Club Tennis.
HighGPA: Having counselors and professors understand the difficulties students have when choosing courses. Sometimes people choose courses simply based on an easy grade distribution, or they choose a certain professor for a course because of a grade distribution. However, I think professors should strive to grade more similarly with one another, and to discuss their teaching styles and see what works and what doesn't.

FirstGen: A significant amount of Homework for 10% of your grade.Having a midterm (or more) after a holiday.
STEM: Being in a relationship was hard. Being there for family events also hard. Showing up for family (funeral, dinner, etc.). Living far from campus also.

STEM: I have a personality disorder, my symptoms including anxiety and depression. Im registered with CAE, without whom Id be lost, but I still struggle more than my peers because of how much more time I need which affects my self esteem

FirstGen: Personally, as a visual learner, some teachers spend too much time on definitions and not enough time on writing down examples that help me to visualize the definitions.
STEM: The culture of competition between other STEM UCLA students (and the pressure of getting good grades as UCLA students) make the curves in classes difficult to deal with, especially in classes with difficult exams where the teachers HAVE to set a curve. Many STEM major students have a generalization of being quiet and not extremely willing to talk, which makes it difficult sometimes to form study groups.
GPA: Being part of a transfer floor and getting to know each other over the struggles we made to get here and finding a club that I can associate myself with helped me feel like I belong here. However, the INTENSE competition within STEM classes makes me feel less like I belong here, because of being on the average range of the spectrum of STEM students (not great grades, but not bad ones either; between a B- and C+ range; even though I get an average A in a GE class), ALMOST feeling like I am out of UCLAs STEM major league
HighGPA: With the issue of STEM major students being generally quiet and since there is a need in the “real world” to collaborate on teams more often, there should be AT LEAST 5-10 minutes spent each class for people to work IN GROUPS (assigned or self-forming) to inspire cooperation instead of competition between UCLA STEM major students

STEM: From high school when I attend AP Physics, I was the only girl in class. Sometimes it may feel a little lonely I guess.
GPA: Overall, all the people I met here are really welcome and nice, Bring me a sense of belonging. However, I know some people despise China and Chinese people for all sorts of reasons, and that makes me upset and sometimes angry.
HighGPA: As a student just finished freshman year, I haven't encounter any large challenge yet. However, I often have worries about the difficulties of getting interns and jobs later in US as international students.

STEM: Since I'm not an outgoing person, sometimes it's hard for me to actively get involved in a group, so when mission comes within a group, I feel hard to make first step.

FirstGen: I found most STEM classes very fast paced and some classes don't provide enough recourses and help.

STEM: People always say asians are supposed to be good at math

FirstGen: Bad professors/lecturers, TA's who cannot explain their thought process, heavy workload for assignments, high grade weight on exams.
STEM: Being a minority student in STEM is difficult. Generally the STEM field is mostly white and Asian. There is a stigma of not being competent enough to join their study groups. Transfers are also typically shunned as well. This makes it very difficult to do well because the study groups helps students do well enough to maintain a certain grade, which raises the curve. Those students not in the study groups are at a significant disadvantage because they are testing against those study groups.
GPA: Transfers are not cared for like UCLA makes it seem before transferring here. Transfer student orientation is a rushed event that forces students to take unnecessary courses and confuses many transfers. Professors, students, and even counselors have made negative remarks regarding me being a transfer student. The only people who care for transfers are other transfers.
HighGPA: Lessen the weight of exams on grading schemes and teach TAs (and even professors) how to explain topics in an understandable manner. Although professors are hired to do research, it does not give them an excuse to be bad lecturers. UCLA should be more inclined to hire professors who can perform both tasks well. Students are always complaining about how confused they are after lectures because their professors can't explain topics well. The STEM field should require some type of speech courses for STEM students because they are future TA's (and some professors) who should be able to help future undergraduates.

FirstGen: I didn't do well in multi-variable calculus and it made is so that the school made it difficult for me to increase my units for summer so that I could finish my minor in time
STEM: I have social anxiety that's been diagnosed by my doctor and because of that, I find it difficult to talk to classmates.
GPA: I feel a sense of belonging every time I see young kids visiting the campus and looking up to me or asking me questions about my experiences.
HighGPA: Make it so that we can take different paths. If someone is not strong in something, give them extra classes to take as a different option that still benefit their major/minor, yet don't set them up to fail at what they are not strong in.

FirstGen: The difficulty, my lack of enjoyment, and poor grades led me to switch from Mechanical Engineering to Statistics.
STEM: Switching majors was one of the most difficult challenges of my life. I had to leave my friends behind. I had to accept that I was a failure in academics for the first time in my life, after being #1 in my class all throughout my childhood. I felt like I let my friends down, my teachers down, my parents down. Imposter syndrome destroyed any of my confidence and self-esteem.  I experienced, and still do from time to time, a true deep sadness and loneliness unlike anything other before I came to UCLA.
GPA: Athletic events provide me with a happiness and sense of belonging that brings me back to when I was a little kid, going to basketball and football games with my family.
HighGPA:
(Speaking from an Engineering perspective)
- Less competition (curved-straight scale is fine, but curved scale pushes people away from each other, and drives students to isolate themselves in fear of helping someone that may do better than them)

-More appreciation of mental health (professors do not really care about anything outside their classes, unless it's a near death experience and do not realize it may be some of their classes that causes this madness)

I can clearly see that the Statistics department is much more aware of these points, and one of the reasons I am grateful that I switched.

FirstGen: As a student in a competitive major, especially in a competitive university, it is very strenuous. There are a lot more competitive, smarter, and hardworking students and that affects the curve, so it is a struggle for students who usually score below the median.
STEM: As a STEM major, I would say that it is very hard emotionally and mentally to keep up with other competitive students, and it makes it stressful to keep up. For example, receiving a B in a class where 50% of the students receive an A brings down your confidence.
GPA: As an international student, the culture in UCLA is very different and it makes it hard for us to hang out with other students other than our own fellow international students.
HighGPA: As a Computer Science major, I feel like the department is pretty lazy and uncaring for students. I would suggest hiring more professors that are more interested in teaching than their research.

FirstGen: Obtaining classes is difficult. The whole enrollment process can be tedious.
STEM: As a woman, I feel I am stereotyped as 'less intelligent' than men.
GPA: Making friends who help each other in class gives me a sense of belonging. Many people at UCLA are unfriendly and rude, and that makes me feel a lack of belonging.
HighGPA: More 'social' events where we can discuss STEM material in an environment that is not demanding, like class.

FirstGen: In some classes there's a high level of requirements on coding but the pre-reqs doesn't help students well enough for coding and it's hard to find the outside help.
STEM: As an international student, I used to write out the answer of the question and omit some writing process. Sometimes it's challenging to hit full grades of the question because I didn't write the process properly even when I got the right answer.
GPA: For coding. TA's OH are full with people so students who are weak at code cannot get the answer as they expected. Moreover, there's no tutoring service.
HighGPA: Maybe provide more tutoring service. And maybe most importantly, open seats and lecs so that it won't be extremely hard for students to get classes.

FirstGen:
Poor high school education: Limited AP courses. Did not have strong calculus, chemistry, or physics background. 

At UCLA: Lectures packed with 300+ students so it is hard to concentrate. Material is presented very fast, and I feel shy to ask questions. Some professors are unapproachable and not engaging. Labs/discussions do not feel useful.
STEM: Winter quarter of my freshmen year, I got symptoms of my autoimmune disease that made it hard for me to walk for about 2 months. Emotional instability from having this disease impacted my grades negatively, as I did not feel like going to class, and was depressed. My self esteem was very low and affect my social life, which then also affected my grades. With regards to cultural issues, I am stressed because I feel like I am always the "odd Asian" because I do not fit the stereotype of the Asian who surpasses in science classes, and instead struggles and barely passes.
GPA: I am not sure of I have ever had a sense of belonging on campus, but I have had plenty of times where I questioned my place here. Those times are when I am struggling a lot keeping up with my classes, and then getting bad grades, eating alone, lying in bed, being unproductive, etc.
HighGPA: Make classroom/lecture settings more engaging my reducing size of 300+ to about 100. It makes a difference for me because I get less distracted. Take attendance so there is incentive to go to class without being unnoticed, and use clickers for quizzes so students have to study for them. Make TAs and professor feel available for the students. Make professors have review sessions. Have consistency with course content and grade distribution, so that students don't feel like it is worse to take it with a certain professor and that affects their grade.

FirstGen: I haven't been exposed to computer science previously, so it's quite difficult for me to learn some programming language at beginning.
STEM: As a girl who want to explore in the STEM field, I need to tackle with the pressure coming from the society wherein most people hold the point that STEM is the boy's field, and girls are not talented in math and science.
GPA: I always feel a sense of belonging at UCLA since there are helpful students and professors who are always willing to help me when I reach out.
HighGPA: There could be more activities and clubs hold to make more students enjoy the interests steming from the STEM field.

FirstGen: Many times I struggled with concepts particularly in math classes and had to spend long hours trying to work through the concepts. These included linear algebra and analysis.
STEM: There’s no particular instances of this
GPA: I felt a lack of belonging occasionally because of the large campus size and the deeply impersonal culture at UCLA
HighGPA: Make study groups and small clubs to give students a bette and more personal experience

FirstGen: Have to take GE courses, which are mostly completely different from a STEM course
STEM: Not familiar with the scientific background of the US
GPA: Since everyone takes his/her own courses, there is seldom classmates who have a strong link to me
HighGPA: Reducing the requirement of culture and historic GE courses

FirstGen: math is definately the nughtmare for a risk management student.
STEM: I am not the talkative type, and only dealing with numbers makes me even worse at comunnicating
GPA: people have circles that you cannot fill in if you come in the middle

FirstGen: CS 33 and CS 35L were completely time-consuming courses that I took, and I received D-'s in both of them as a result of experiencing anxiety over starting projects.
STEM: I was experiencing a lot of depressive symptoms (such as gaining weight, not being able to get out of bed until really late, oversleeping, lack of interest in things I used to enjoy) during my second year in college due in part to the death of a friend and an overwhelming living situation. This made my time extra difficult, and I failed a class for the first time in my fall quarter of that year.
GPA: I felt a sense of belonging on this campus as a STEM major when I helped start the club Diversity and Inclusion in Product and Data, which aims to create a better space for minorities to grow in those particular fields. I felt a lack of belonging when I realized I was one of few females in my computer science classes.
HighGPA: Please please please don't create classes like Computer Science 33 and Computer Science 35L. These classes simply aren't realistic expectations of students and don't teach students anything- every single person I've ever spoken to has admitted to using Github during their time in those classes, and for that reason, it simply doesn't seem WORTH it. Not only are students not fully learning, but they're losing sleep, morale, and confidence over them.

GPA: emails from department
HighGPA: provide more job opportunities

FirstGen: I came to UCLA as a Mathematics-Economics Major. My background in math was extensive; however, until college I was taught math in a conceptual, problem-solving way. The math courses that I took in UCLA focused more on proofs of theorems and understanding how they are derived. This change made math classes harder for me.
STEM: Being put in a highly competitive environment and not performing to my expectations made me question my place in the STEM major.
GPA: I hail from a small town in India with a very small population. Upon coming to UCLA and suddenly finding myself in the midst of 40,000 undergraduates, I felt a sense of disconnect from other students. It felt like being a small fish in a big pond and thus, I felt aloof from all the other students. Furthermore, STEM classes were always filled with a large number of students and it was harder to form meaningul relationships with students in classes.
HighGPA:
Potential suggestions include:
1. Create a less competitive environment by promoting more collabaration within a large class through group projects.
2. More opportunities for extra credit and decrease pressure from a fast paced quarter system.

FirstGen: Curving against the best interest of a student.
STEM: There will continue to be emotional challenges and mental health crises so long as students are pressured to outperform one another in competitive courses.
GPA: The deepest learning I have experienced in college has not taken place in the classroom. Student organizations provide opportunities for growth that are not possible within a lecture hall.
HighGPA: I suggest implementing some type of peer network that is recognized within the syllabi of each STEM course.
Sometimes it is difficult to enroll in important courses, and therefore a four-year courses plan of STEM majors may need to change many times.

FirstGen:
There are very few professors who are interested in teaching. 
Discussion sections are often taught like lectures, and office hours are often very busy which makes it difficult to get questions answered in a comfortable setting in many classes.
STEM: People are not very friendly in my math classes (applied math is my intended major), and they are very competitive which is a destructive learning environment.
GPA: This campus has a very impersonal feel due to its size. There are many facilities available and many opportunities to take advantage of, however there is little student support which leads to a detached feeling from the campus.
HighGPA: Smaller class sizes, more friendly professors who would actually like to be teaching (thank you Professor Esfandiari, as I feel you care about student learning and that is motivating). A more interactive learning environment that uses recommended video lectures and tutorials (like khan academy), as opposed to textbooks. Visual learning is much more helpful than textbooks for many students.

FirstGen: The professor is not clear on teaching students
GPA: The Bruin bear
HighGPA: If the professor can teach us more systematically during the class, more student will do better.

FirstGen: The general assumptions of professors that the student knows a specific subject
STEM: Emotional: it creates a lot of stress on the students because the time you invest on working is way more than other majors and sometimes, you don't really have help from anyone except your book. For international students, things that are happening back home (country level wise) creates an extra weight on them that local students do not really have to deal with
GPA: Nothing specific jumps to mind
HighGPA: Give a list of subjects and important points the students should know before starting a class. This will give the opportunity for all the students to have a good base and to be able to understand everything the professor says

FirstGen: For a STEM major, we have to actually understand the concept of for example, a formula, to be able to apply it to different problems. It is the most challenging part as a STEM major. Sometimes, I feel like I understand the concept but I can not do the problems.
STEM: When I was in my Freshmen year, my mother passed away. I was not able to focus on school work because of my emotional hardship. It was a difficult time because not only that I had family problem, but also a cultural problem. It was hard to adapt to such a bigger environment. We have bigger classes here so I have to get used to study independently.
GPA: I love how UCLA has a big variety of language classes and cultural clubs. I was able to find the people that I can get along with easier.
HighGPA: I hope that professors will have a more organized notes so we can follow easier.

FirstGen: This happened in computer programming courses. I have never been more miserable than when I was in a PIC course here at UCLA. I never got any programming experience prior to the course, and to come into the most introductory class and have a preset curve AND 40% of kids already have experience is just infuriating to be honest. I was lost the whole time, my professor was rude and unhelpful, my mental health declined as a result. The academic issues arise when people are experts in a domain already and take intro courses, AND when there are mandatory curves that the department adheres to, which is utterly ridiculous. If someone works their ass off to learn the material and then just HAPPENS to be in a class with 10 more gifted students than someone from a different quarter, that could be the difference between a B and a C.
STEM: Exactly the same thing as above, except I want to add that there is a greater lack of cultural/social/ethnic diversity in STEM fields. Also unsettling.
GPA: All of these questions are going to relate back to what I first talked about. I did NOT feel anything near a sense of belonging in that programming course, especially in comparison to how much I enjoyed my social science classes. STEM is riddled with people who are basically breezing through certain things because they have had childhood exposure as a kid, and it takes away the whole idea of learning and making college a collaborative, eye-opening experience. Instead, I'm worried about if the kids around me guessed a question correct that I got wrong, and might take my "spot" in the limited amount of A's that are given out.
HighGPA: NO DEPARTMENT GRADE CUTOFFS. 14% A's for Math? I have no words for that.  Yes I understand we want to stay away from grade inflation, but the fact is, you are putting your students at a disadvantage in the career field if they get a meager 3.0 but happened to still perform in the top majority percentile in their classes. Misleading...

FirstGen: Passing the vigorous exams that do not test for understanding or practical/fundamental knowledge but rather exam-taking strategies and utilise obscure mathematical/algebra techniques to solve the question.
STEM: Being within a STEM major, there is more social pressure to perform well. STEM major's also have a competitive culture which dissuades collaboration.
GPA: The assignment structure; working on the homework as a group created a sense of belonging, it is a good chance to meet different people and feel apart of the campus.
HighGPA: Lectures should be more structured so that it is less confusing.

Major: my name is xuelian zhang major statistics
GPA: teamwork
HighGPA: more easier

FirstGen: I think STEM is just difficult, and my high school did not prepare me well enough for the rigor of college. I didn't experience any academic issues per se, but I was one of the top students in my high school, and never really learned how to study effectively (let alone study at all). Homework and tests just got harder, and I couldn't keep up with them. I underestimated how much time I needed to put into my projects and didn't allocate enough time. I realized that procrastinating is very bad for the time consuming CS projects. Thus, the transition into college was difficult and my grades didn't fare too well. Additionally, the other students in my classes are really smart, so competing with them for grades is challenging.
STEM: Being born in America, I haven't really experienced any cultural or social issues that might have made it challenging. This might sound really weird, but I actually think that because of the privileged situation I was born into, I became lazy. My parents, having immigrated to America, had to work very hard from a young age to help their families survive. I on the other hand, have been very blessed and placed in a financially stable family due to the hard work of my parents. In a sense, I'm spoiled and just never felt the urgency to work hard in school as the fear of not having money or food never isn't real to me. This laziness does actually contribute to my academic performance. It is obviously not proven that my upbringing is the reason why I am so aloof, but this is just my opinion.  Anyway, I feel many students procrastinate and such, but many still have a drive to do well and succeed that leads to action. Me on the other hand, would very much like to do better, but this desire isn't enough to push me to action. I'm okay with the C's that I get though I would like A's and B's. All of this plus poor time management skills plus all of the opportunities to socialize in college just add together to make studying difficult.
GPA: I found a Christian fellowship on campus and the environment has been very welcoming from day one. All the people in the fellowship are extremely nice and have treated me like family. I am welcome in their homes, we study together, eat together, and just live life together. They have been a very influential part of who I am today.
HighGPA: I would say that high schools could prepare students better. Obviously, this is out of UCLA's control, and some schools don't have the resources to improve this. Everything I can think of lies in the student's themselves and not on the school, so this is very difficult. I think maybe encourage a mindset of learning rather than getting grades. It's very difficult when the world places so much value on the GPA, but I think this could help students develop a healthier mindset about school. Yeah, I can't think of much. Sorry.

FirstGen: My parents left to Mexico when I graduated high school, so i pretty much had to work a full time job while taking classes. Overall this affected my grades.
STEM: Being a minority in a class where the class is predominately Asian, it is kind of intimidating and it is kind of hard to make friends, I feel as if everyone has their own group of friends within their own and being possibly the only Latino in some classes, it is kind of challenging.
GPA: Vivian Lew is a great professor, when going to her office hours she really took to the time to help out and told me I was doing great in the class even though I felt like I did not belong at all in the class.
HighGPA: Provide more help like for example tutoring free of charge aside from office hours.

FirstGen: Classes close too quickly and some of the professor's aren't good at all which makes it hard to not only understand but also do well in the class
STEM: homesickness. Since I am an international student, I miss home a lot which makes it difficult to not get distracted or sad during class
GPA: Close friends and extremely helpful professors who want you to do well
HighGPA: create enough classes for students to take classes that interest them

GPA: UCLA is really big and there are many teachers and staff, sometimes it is hard for me to find someone for help when I encounter some difficulties. However, responsible teachers and teaching assistants give me a sense of belonging.

FirstGen: Some people think women are unable to make contributions in math. Thus less encourage for me to study math when I were in high school.
STEM: Studying math are usually seen as you want to be a math teacher. I am not saying it is a bad choice, but women major in math can have a wider options than people think.
GPA: We have tutorial meeting each semester, and the talking makes me feel I am important to the school. Also, the animals in our school are really a typical symbol as a sense of belonging.

GPA: classmates and professors
HighGPA: ask help from tutor

Major: 1. Computational & Systems Biology, 2. Microbiology, Immunology, & Molecular Genetics
FirstGen: A lot of life science curriculum is based on memorization of detailed processes, so I felt like many times I could understand something but not recall it word for word on an exam, making it difficult to succeed in class.
STEM: STEM can be isolating - it's quite cutthroat at times given the grade deflation and curved classes, so sometimes it's hard to cooperate with classmates to create a better collective learning experience.
GPA: I think the biggest thing is finding clubs and social groups that you are interested in, because it's easy to feel lost in such a big university, and having a dedicated group of friends and a hobby helps you get through the rigor of UCLA.
HighGPA: Allow second chances more.  Students have to balance work, classes, living independently, and a host of other things, and it's hard to be performing perfectly every moment of every day.  Every midterm and large assignment is big enough to tank your grade at UCLA, and it's impossible to stay on top of everything.  If a student learns the material well overall, that should be indicated in the grade more than a crushing week leading to a late assignment or an hour long headache leading to a failed midterm.

FirstGen: English terminology in this major, multiple resources in studying, sometimes I don`t know which information is real, which is not.
STEM: I study with my tutor in his lab, I can tell that we almost do the same things everyday, sometimes it would be a little bit boring and it could drive me crazy when there is no progress for a long time.

FirstGen: In college study before transfer, my math course got great grades,

FirstGen: I took most of my courses relate to Computer Science or Engineering major in community college, however, I am an Economics major student. I think it's challenging to take Physics and Chemistry to me, so I decide not go in deeper. But I was interesting in it in a mathematical way.
STEM: I think there is a male majority in the STEM majors. When I think of STEM major, mostly will link to the males. Also, I think STEM majors' students are highly talented that they might change the world. Most of the students think STEM majors only belong to smart persons.
GPA: During the sports game, I strongly feel like I belong to UCLA. haha
HighGPA: Make one of the requirement classes(general education) relate to STEM majors, so more students will get a sense of how STEM majors actually look like.

FirstGen: Coming into college, I thought I was great at math. After taking math 32A/B, 33A, 61, I was mistaken. Just getting a B in these classes feels like such a tall task, they demand so much from you. The math exams here are comparable to reinventing the wheel.
STEM: Growing up in a typical Korean American household, academic expectations are always high. The parents expect six-figure salaries early in your career and they see any non-stem field as useless. Some anxiety issues have also complicated my concentration and study habits.
GPA: When trying to form study groups with peers in my stem (specifically math/stats classes), if a second goes by where I'm not 100% proactive and investing time in the other person while they aren't being fully diligent either, they pretty much drop you. The elitism here is really cumbersome, and my grades have suffered at times due to unsuccessful efforts in creating a lasting, effective study group. It just feels like you're being used simply for a grade, and once the class is over, that's that. They don't want to be your friend or make any outside effort to connect.
HighGPA: Back when I was deciding between colleges, UCSD was my other top choice. Admitted as a CS major, one thing I noticed was that their CS department is huge on having tutoring hours for all their CS classes, and fostering more student collaboration. This is valuable for gaining teamwork experience and students can only benefit from this by participating. TA and professor hours can be intimidating and crowded, so creating a strong, collaborative tutoring system would be great. Nobody there was cut-throat competitive or worried that helping someone else would "bring down the curve and thus disadvantage me." It'd be nice if UCLA could have a culture where students don't see each other as merely data points on a bell curve. UCLA could implement this system for STEM majors, specifically for mathematics and statistics majors.

FirstGen: Some textbooks complicate things and are hard to understand. If the professor is also not clear in presenting the materials, it becomes frustrating.
STEM: The first time when I realized that math is not about numbers and calculation but about logic and proofs.
GPA: The only STEM class I took at UCLA is a stats class. A lot of resources were given; the textbook was clear; there were additional assessment assignments that were very useful.
HighGPA: Allow slow transition (of thinking process) for new college students.

GPA: joining labs and participating in their projects give me a sense of belonging
HighGPA: provide STEM students opportunities to meet with each other and help each other out

FirstGen: Not seeing it being applied or seeing the purpose of what I am learning.
STEM: As a first-generation Mexican American Female student, I would find myself lowering my own expectations and putting myself down. For example, I would be in a math or data class and I'll tell myself that I am not expected to do well so I use that as an excuse to not complete a homework assignment or study properly for an exam.

FirstGen: A lot of competitions at UCLA with a very diverse background, experiences, and high GPA scares me that I won't be able to find a job after graduation

FirstGen: Chem 20A is one of the hardest courses for me, partly because I'm not good at chemistry since middle school. However, I also felt some knowledge we taught in that class required extra physics knowledge which we did not have time to talk explicitly in the class. Also, for me the content of that course is too much to teach in just one quarter. The professor tried his best, but we still kept rushing to the end. Even if the score I get was not bad, I believed that I did not fully understand the content. Many students have the similar feelings in the class. Another big challenge is math.  Most stem courses I took so far are math. I felt I can handle the ordinary lower division math courses, but the honor course and upper division course are difficult and time-consuming. The honor course Math 32BH is extremely challenging for me, because the classmates are very competitive and the content of that course is so much harder than the parallel courses.
STEM: At first I put too much stress on myself and believed I should do well in every math, part of the reason is because I came from China. As a result,  I was very nervous when taking every math course. It turned out the math courses are harder and my classmates are more competitive than I thought. At the same time, I worried that whether the courses we taught here were easier than the courses students took in China. I worried whether I could be more competitive than my high school classmates who took math in China.  Now I felt more relaxed and focused more on the knowledge itself to enjoy the math.
GPA: Although Math 32BH is so far the hardest course I took, it is also the course in which I made most friends. I felt happy to talk with these students who share the same interest as me. In other math courses, I also made friends and we can review for exams together.
HighGPA: Personally, I believed it would be better if there are more STEM competitions, such as data hackathon and more research opportunities for STEM students.

FirstGen: Enrollment issues. Especially for some of the stats classes like 101c or 102c which is only offered during the fall, I was not able to enroll in those classes, delaying my graduation.
STEM: I feel like I am not as smart as most of the other STEM students, making me as if I am not fit as a STEM major
GPA: I feel a lack of belonging to the campus since I'm not as happy as everyone else in the campus. I don't feel like I am involved as well
HighGPA: Provide more open spots for stem classes

FirstGen: I thought the most challenging issues as a STEM major is how to compete with other students and how to survive in the world of smart students.
STEM: My family give me a freedom to choose on what major I like, not merely demanding me to join STEM majors, but I individually choose to be one, as I like STEM as a interesting thing to be explored.
GPA: I feel much appreciated belongs to UCLA big families as it gives me new challenges and also a new way on how I face the world.
HighGPA: To be more lenient in grading and how teachers approaches student with less capability compare to other average students.

FirstGen: The STEM courses are difficult to master for student wanting to understand materials thoroughly.
STEM: Asians have to perform way better as well as maintain much higher GPA than others in order to succeed in the field.
GPA: People are too independent so sometimes it is difficult to find someone else to ask for help and study together.
HighGPA: Organize more programs to help STEM major communicate and learn together.

FirstGen: The math courses I took at UCLA provided the biggest challenge to me. At one point it made me reevaluate my major. The difficulty of the classes along with lack of empathy from certain professors made me stress greatly while taking these courses.
STEM: In my experience as a STEM major, I feel that there are very few other hispanic student that are also STEM majors. There were times that this made me feel secluded from other groups in class which discourage me  to work with other groups.
GPA: I think being in AAP made me feel a sense of belonging because I was able to work with peers and create relationships with other students that were taking the same classes as me.
HighGPA: I think somehow structuring STEM  classes so that your final grade is not just dependent on 2/3 exams would GREATLY reduce stress on students. There were many times that I put in hours of work and still felt unsure if I would even pass the class. Many times the grade I received exams were not reflections of the amount of time I put forth studying.

STEM: Sometimes it is tough to discuss with my classmates on some topics, since English is not my first language.
HighGPA: I think the challenges I've met so far are managaeble.

FirstGen: I did one statistic-related course butI didn't choose statistic major when I went to usyd, because I struggled to understand the importance of science and cannot see the connection between what we learn in the classroom and the happenings of the real world.And I felt science subjects being too difficult or too boring, because we either do math all the time or need to learn statistic computing at the same time when we studied theoretical concepts.
STEM: when I first came to the college, I heard many students talking about how difficult a STEM major could be and you may be at greater risk of not even finishing college.  Given these concerns, many of us are choosing the pathway that seems not that difficult such as marketing and economics.
GPA: I feel sense of belonging when I have more frequent interactions with lecturer and TA.TA and lecturer of stats20 make a very good effort to help students to communicate by having online chat system and holding many office hours.
HighGPA: I think mentoring is an important tool that community colleges can employ to encourage persistence in STEM majors. mentoring is very effective when students have multiple mentors that can provide guidance across a variety of different areas. Students are more likely to continue as STEM majors when they experience encouragement and emotional support. academic support and career coaching.

FirstGen: My school's STEM fields were fairly weak so I felt under-prepared coming into college and taking high level STEM courses.
GPA: The people in my major came from similar backgrounds as I did and they were all very helpful and comforting in times where I was having a hard time.
HighGPA: More active SEASmentors who reach out and offer advice based on your specific situation or refer you to others who went through a similar situation that you are thinking about.

FirstGen: Sometimes, the professor expects too much on students' self-learning ability, which makes no sense for paying this much tuition. For example, in my stats 102 class, prof never teaches computer science and TA only talks about pseudocode and flowchart, while they expect the students to write games in R. It adds a lot of burden that don't make this class valuable.
STEM: Can't really remember an issue for this.
GPA: The professors of some classes, like chem 20AH and 20BH, provide a lot of help during and after lectures. They make me feel very comfortable and learn a lot.
HighGPA: Have more experienced profs to offer class in greater explanations.

FirstGen: I believe the quarter system is incredibly detrimental to STEM majors. My personal experience in UCLA STEM, mostly math classes with some physics and programming,  has been full of discouragement. If I don't get a subject, I feel dumb, but I have to remember that this is the first time I'm seeing this and it isn normal to not understand right away. Like with anything, it takes time and practice to become good at something, time that isn't available in a quarter system. Sometimes there are people who get things right away, and that makes it really difficult for the rest of us. Often I feel like if I had just a little more time I would be able to do much better in my classes. In STEM classes more than any other type of class, your entire grade is based on exams. No other assignments and barely any points for homework. This makes it very difficult for those who struggle with test taking. I have developed test taking anxiety just from attending UCLA. I have never gotten an A in a math class. Mostly B's and some C's. Which makes my STEM GPA very low compared to other majors at UCLA. It is unfortunate that many STEM students will undoubtedly have a lower GPA that north campus majors.
STEM: The best STEM majors are often just focused on school. I prioritize my health, sleep, and well-being ahead of school most of the times. I have to be up very early for rowing team practices. Other people enjoy hanging out with friends and being social at night. It is very difficult to do this as a STEM major.
GPA: Professors can make a big difference on this sense of belonging. How they respond to different students, how willing they are to help and make adjustments, and what they expect all cater to different types of students. If a professor doesn't have time for the type of student you are, you feel behind and like you are not supposed to be here.
HighGPA: Many math classes are 3 days a week for 50 minutes. It is hard to digest anything in this time. I would prefer longer classes. More personable TA's. Consistent degrees of exam difficulty among professors (especially professors teaching the same course). BRUINCASTING LECTURES!! Only 1 of my math classes has been bruincasted. All of my north campus friends' lectures are bruincasted. Less emphasis on grades and more on learning. More evenly distributed grades- i.e. not having your entire grade based on 2 tests. Does not promote learning, just fear and cramming.

GPA: Can't get why they are so happy at the frat party
HighGPA: Please carefully supervise the design of certain courses so the students won't be overwhelmed. There is a difference between need us to work hard to learn the material and kill us with the unreasonable workload. Please carefully listen to the feed back from students. If the majority are overwhelmed, it is not simply complains out of laziness.

FirstGen: A lot of the math related courses in my major were little bit challenging.
STEM: As a STEM major there weren't any challenging issues coming from emotion, social, or culture.
GPA: A lot of the club activities related to my major helped me build social boundaries around the people who have similar goals in life.
HighGPA: I think the core part of the assist STEM major students need is the help on finding a right job/career. A lot of the times students even in the senior year are not too sure what they want to do in their life and even the ones that do know still get a hard time finding the job related to what they want. And so I think it will be greatly helpful if STEM majors at UCLA give out little bit more help outside courses(such as club activities).

FirstGen: Each math class that I've taken at UCLA, I haven't gotten better than a B+. That was quite a shock coming from expecting As in high school. The decreased achievement left an impression on me that was difficult to overcome and made it easier to withdraw from classes and friendships.
STEM: I was dealing with deepening depression in my junior and senior years, which occurred at the same time as my decision to take up a statistics minor. It became difficult to communicate with teachers and friends about my classes and how I was doing as I feared that they would judge me for the difficulties that I was having.
GPA: Joining a club at UCLA - mock trial - certainly helped. Opening up to friends about the difficulties that I was having and talking to teachers about improving my situation were very helpful to me. In general, having people to talk to increased my sense of belonging.
HighGPA: The expectations of STEM classes are higher than in other classes. That increased difficulty can become wearing and isolating. Teacher's have to make sure that students don't become isolated and can continue to enjoy the learning, despite the difficulties inherent in the class. Organizing group work can assist with this, as long as group work is truly done collaboratively. Giving opportunities to make up work that was done poorly so that students don't become so stressed that their grade - and then their GPA and their futures - is going to permanently suffer could help to mitigate the wear. Otherwise, having a close relationship between teacher and student, as well among students, allows students to reach out when they are struggling. Explicit encouragement for students to reach out can be helpful as well.

STEM: Hard to find fellow student to cooperate with

FirstGen: Situations in which academic issues made it challenging as a STEM major, is during a class as you begin to go over a new topic, professors give examples without giving basic knowledge about it. Although it is expected for a high degree of background knowledge, as it is UCLA, using online material to get a more simplified version of material, then going over the examples that a professor her at UCLA gives is very helpful.
STEM: Socially, STEM majors are expected to be smart and study all the time. However, UCLA has a very social environment which makes it hard to be able to study all the time, thus making a STEM major difficult.
GPA: An example, is during a particular class you seem to be getting the information well. However once the material ramps up, I begin to not understand but the peers around me do. A sense of competition makes it hard to ask the peers around me and so I often try to learn the material by myself without asking anyone around me for help.
HighGPA: Ways to help minimize the challenges for STEM majors are to be more basic in the information they first hand, before ramping up the difficulty in concepts. This allows the information to have a strong foundation and we as students are able to build upon the basic concepts.

FirstGen: In order to graduate on time, I have to take multiple STEM classes per quarter, which makes each quarter stressful because I don't have any easy classes that I can use as a cushion for my GPA and I have to spend tons of time learning the material, studying, reviewing, asking questions, and doing homework for each class in order to do well. It cuts into my free time and makes it harder for me to devote time to my extracurriculars.
STEM: If I'm not taking care of myself (ie getting very little sleep, eating lots of junk food, not exercising, not discussing my problems with my loved ones) my mental health gets worse which makes it much harder to motivate myself to study, do homework, go to office hours, etc. Because I spend less time on schoolwork, my grades suffer, and I spend even less time taking care of myself to try and raise my grades (staying up late and eating junk food to cram for exams and finish homework). It's a horrible cycle.
GPA: I felt like I belonged on campus once I started getting involved in extracurricular activities like the Statistics Club, DevX, and being a learning assistant for lower div math. It made me feel like I'd found a community of people to belong to, and that in turn made me feel like I belonged at UCLA.
HighGPA: CAPS is severely understaffed, so hiring more professionals at CAPS so students can actually get more free appointments or get appointments sooner would be great. Also, just having professors that emphasize the importance of taking care of yourself and are understanding towards issues like mental and physical health problems, working part time, etc would be amazing.
